respStmt.name: Keenan Jones with homographing and regularisation by Alexis Antonia

publicationStmt.publisher: Imprinted at London by W.W. for Cutbert Burby.

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declaration.
Ferdinand, king of Navarre Berowne, lord attending on the king Dumain, lord attending on the king Longaville, lord attending on the king Princess of France Don Adriano de Armado, a fantastical Spaniard Moth, page to Armado Prologue Ensemble Song
Costard, a clown Boyet, lord attending on the princess of France Rosaline, lady attending on the princess Katharine, lady attending on the princess Maria, lady attending on the princess Mercade, lord attending on the princess of France Holofernes, a schoolmaster Sir Nathaniel, a curate Dull, a constable Jaquenetta, a country wench Forester First Lord

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following

body.head: A PLEASANT Conceited Comedie CALLED, Loves labors lost. As it was presented before her Highnes this last Christmas. Newly corrected and augmented By W. Shakespere.

div2.stage: Enter Ferdinand K. of Nauar, Berowne, Longauill, and Dumaine.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand.
sp.l: LET Fame, that all hunt after in their lives,
Live registered upon our brazen Tombs,
And then grace us, in the disgrace of death:
When spite of cormorant devouring Time,
The endeavour of this present breath may buy:
That honour which shall bate his scythes keen edge,
And make us heirs of all eternity.
Therefore brave Conquerors, for so you are,
That war against your own affections,
And the huge army of the worlds desires.
Our late edict shall strongly stand in force,
Nauar shall be the wonder of the world.
Our Court shall be a little Academy,
Still and contemplative in living art.
You three, Berowne, Dumaine, and Longauill,
Have sworn for three years term, to live with me:
My fellow Scholars, and to keep those statutes
That are recorded in this schedule here.
Your oaths are past, and now subscribe your names:
That his own hand may strike his honour down,
That violates the smallest branch herein.
If you are armed to do, as sworn to do,
Subscribe to your deep oaths, and keep it too.

sp.speaker: Longauill.
sp.l: I am resolved, it is but a thee years fast:
The mind shall banquet, though the body pine,
Fat paunches have lean pates: and dainty bits
Make rich the ribs, but bankrupt quite the wits.

sp.speaker: Dumaine
sp.l: My loving Lord, Dumaine is mortified,
The grosser manner of these worlds delights:
He throws upon the gross worlds baser slaves
A pleasant conceited Comedy:
To love, to wealth, to pomp, I pine and die,
With all these living in Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Berowne.
sp.l: I can but say their protestation over,
So much dear Liege, I have already sworn,
That is, to live and study here three years.
But there are other strict observances:
As not to see a woman in that term,
Which I hope well is not enrolled there.
And one day in a week to touch no food:
And but one meal on every day beside:
The which I hope is not enrolled there.
And then to sleep but three hours in the night,
And not be seen to wink of all the day.
When I was wont to think no harm all night,
And make a dark night too of half the day:
Which I hope well is not enrolled there.
O these are barren tasks, too hard to keep,
Not to see Ladies, study, fast, not sleep.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Your oath is past, to pass away from these.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: Let me say no my liege, and if you please,
I only swore to study with your grace,
And stay here in your Court for three years space.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: You swore to that Berowne, and to the rest.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: By yea and nay sir, then I swore in jest.
What is the end of study, let me know?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Why that to know which else we should not know.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Things hid and bard (you mean) from common sense.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Aye, that is studies god-like recompense.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Come on then, I will swear to study so,
To know the thing I am forbid to know:
As thus, to study where I well may dine,
When I to fast expressly am forbid.
Or study where to meet some Mistress fine.
When Mistresses from common sense are hid.
Or having sworn too hard a keeping oath,
Study to break it, and not break my troth.
If studies gain be thus, and this be so,
Study knows that which yet it doth not know,
Swear me to this, and I will never say no.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: These be the stops that hinder study quit,
And train our intellects to vain delight.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Why? all delights are vain, but that most vain
Which with pain purchased, doth inherit pain,
As painfully to pore upon a Book,
To seek the light of truth, while truth the while
Doth falsely blind the eye-sight of his look:
Light seeking light, doth light of light beguile:
Soever you find where light in darkness lies,
Your light grows dark by loosing of your eyes.
Study me how to please the eye in deed,
By fixing it upon a fairer eye,
Who dazzling so, that eye shall be his heed,
And give him light that it was blinded by.
Study is like the heavens glorious Sun,
That will not be deep searched with saucy looks:
Small have continual plodders ever won,
Save base authority from others Books.
These earthly Godfathers of heavens lights,
That give a name to every fixed Star,
Have no more profit of their shining nights,
Than those that walk and wot not what they are.
Too much to know, is to know naught but fame:
And every Godfather can give a name.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: How well he is read to reason against reading.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Proceeded well, to stop all good proceeding.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: He weeds the corn, and still lets grow the weeding.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: The Spring is near when green geese are abreeding.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: How follows that?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Fit in his place and time.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: In reason nothing.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Something then in rime.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Berowne is like an envious sneaping Frost,
That bites the first born infants of the Spring.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Well, say I am, why should proud Summer boast,
Before the Birds have any cause to sing?
Why should I joy in any abortive birth?
At Christmas I no more desire a Rose,
Than wish a Snow in May's new fangled shows:
But like of each thing that in season grows.
So you to study now it is too late,
Climb over the house to unlock the little gate.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Well, sit you out: go home Berowne: adieu.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: No my good Lord, I have sworn to stay with you.
And though I have for barbarism spoke more
Than for that Angel knowledge you can say,
Yet confident I will keep what I have sworn,
And bide the penance of each three years day.
Give me the paper, let me read the same,
And to the strictest decrees I will write my name.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: How well this yielding rescues thee from shame.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Item, That no woman shall come within a mile of
my Court.
Hath this been proclaimed?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Four days ago.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Let us see the penalty.
On pain of loosing her tongue.
Who devised this penalty?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Marry that did I.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Sweet Lord and why?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: To fright them hence with that dread penalty.
A dangerous law against gentility.
Item, If any man be seen to talk with a woman within
the term of three years, he shall endure such public
shame as the rest of the Court can possible devise.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: This Article my liege yourself must break,
For well you know here comes in Embassy,
The French king's daughter with yourself to speak:
A Maid of grace and complete majesty,
About surrender up of Aquitaine,
To her decrepit, sick, and bedrid Father.
Therefore this Article is made in vain,
Or vainly comes the admired Princess hither.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: What say you Lords? why, this was quite forgot.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: So Study evermore is overshot,
While it doth study to have what it would,
It doth forget to do the thing it should:
And when it hath the thing it hunteth most,
It is won as towns with fire, so won so lost.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: We must of force dispense with this Decree,
She must lie here on mere necessity.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Necessity will make us all forsworn
Three thousand times within this three years space:
For every man with his affects is born,
Not by might mastered, but by special grace.
If I break faith, this word shall speak for me,
I am forsworn on mere necessity.
So to the Laws at large I write my name,
And he that breaks them in the least degree,
Stands in attainder of eternal shame.
Suggestions are to other as to me:
But I believe although I seem so loath,
I am the last that will last keep his oath.
But is there no quick recreation granted?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Aye that there is, our Court you know is haunted
With a refined traveller of Spaine,
A man in all the worlds new fashion planted,
That hath a mint of phrases in his brain:
On who the music of his own vain tongue
Doth ravish like enchanting harmony:
A man of complements whom right and wrong
Have chose as umpire of their mutiny.
This child of Fancy that Armado hight,
For interim to our studies shall relate,
In high borne words the worth of many a Knight:
From tawny Spaine lost in the worlds debate.
How you delight my Lords I know not I,
But I protest I love to hear him lie,
And I will use him for my Minstrelsy.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Armado is a most illustrious wight,
A man of fire new words, Fashions own knight.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Costard the swain and he, shall be our sport,
And so to study three years is but short.

div2.stage: Enter a Constable with Costard with a letter.

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p: Which is the Dukes own person?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: This fellow, What wouldst?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
I myself reprehend his own person, for I am his
graces Farborough: But I would see his own person
in flesh and blood.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: This is he.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Seignior Arme Arme commends you:
There is villainy abroad, this letter will tell you more.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Sir the Contents thereof are as touching me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: A letter from the magnificent Armado.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: How low soever the matter, I hope in God for high words.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: A high hope for a low heaven. God grant us patience

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: To hear, or forbear hearing.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
To hear meekly sir, and to laugh moderately, or
to forbear both.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p:
Well sir, be it as the style shall give us cause to clime
in the merriness.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
The matter is to me sir, as concerning Iaquenetta:
The manner of it is, I was taken with the manner.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: In what manner?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
In manner and form following sir all those three.
I was seen with her in the Manner house, sitting with her
upon the Form, and taken following her into the Park:
which put together, is in manner and form following.
Now sir for the manner, It is the manner of a man to speak
to a woman, for the form in some form.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: For the following sir.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
As it shall follow in my correction, and God defend
the right.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Will you hear this Letter with attention?

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: As we would hear an Oracle.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Such is the simplicity of man to hearken after the flesh

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
GReat Deputy the welkins Vizgerent, and sole dominatur of
Nauar, my souls earths God, and bodies fostering patron:

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: Not a word of Costart yet.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: So it is

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p:
It may be so: but if he say it is so, he is in telling true:
but so.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Be to me, and every man that dares not fight.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: No words.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Of other men's secrets I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
So it is besieged with sable coloured melancholy, I did
commend the black oppressing humour to the most wholesome physic
of thy health-giving air: And as I am a Gentleman, betook myself
to walk: the time When? about the sixth hour, When Beasts
most graze, Birds best peck, and Men sit down to that nourishment
which is called Supper: So much for the time When. Now for the
ground Which? which I mean I walked upon, it is yclipped Thy Park.
Then for the place Where? where I mean, I did encounter that obscene and most preposterous event that draweth from my snow-white pen the
ebon coloured Ink, which here thou viewest, beholdest, surveyest, or
seest. But to the place Where? It standeth North North-east and by
East from the West corner of thy curious knotted garden; There
did I see that low spirited Swain, that base Minnow of thy mirth,

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Me?
that unlettered small knowing soul,

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Me?
that shallow vassal

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Still me.

which as I remember,
hight Costard,

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: O me

sorted and consorted contrary to
thy established proclaimed Edict and continent Cannon: Which
with, o with, but with this I passion to say wherewith:

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: With a Wench.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
With a child of our Grandmother Eve, a female; or for thy
more sweet understanding a Woman: him, I (as my ever esteemed
duty pricks me on) have sent to thee, to receive the meed of punishment
by thy sweet Graces Officer Anthonie Dull, a man of
good repute, carriage bearing, and estimation.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Me if it shall please you? I am Anthony Dull.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
For Iaquenetta (so is the weaker vessel called) which I
apprehended with the aforesaid Swain, I keep her as a vessel of
thy Laws fury, and shall at the least of thy sweet notice, bring
her to trial. Thine in all complements of devoted and heart-burning
heat of duty.
Don Adriano de Armado.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
This is not so well as I looked for, but the best that
ever I heard.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Aye the best, for the wost. But sirrah, What say you to this?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Sir I confess the Wench.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Did you hear the Proclamation?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I do confess much of the hearing it, but little of the
marking of it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
It was proclaimed a years imprisonment to be taken
with a Wench.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I was taken with none sir, I was taken with a Damsel.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Well, it was proclaimed Damsel.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: This was no Damsel neither sir, she was a Virgin.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: It is so varied too, for it was proclaimed Virgin.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
If it were, I deny her Virginity: I was taken with a
Maid.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: This Maid will not serve your turn sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: This Maid will serve my turn sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Sir I will pronounce your sentence: You shall fast a
week with Bran and Water.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I had rather pray a month with Mutton and Porridge.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: And Don Armado shall be your keeper.
sp.l: My Lord Berowne, see him delivered over,
And go we Lords to put in practise that,
Which each to other hath so strongly sworn.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: I will lay my Head to any good man's Hat,
These oaths and laws will prove an idle scorn.
Sirrah, Come on.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I suffer for the truth sir: for true it is, I was taken
with Iaquenetta, and Iaquenetta is a true girl, and therefore
welcome the sour Cup of prosperity, affliccio may one day
smile again, and till then sit thee down sorrow.

div2.stage: Enter Armado and Moth his page.

sp.speaker: Armado.
sp.p:
Boy, What sign is it when a man of great spirit
grows melancholy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A great sign sir that he will look sad.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Why? sadness is one and the self same thing dear imp.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No no, O Lord sir no.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
How canst thou part sadness and melancholy, my
tender Juvenal?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
By a familiar demonstration of the working, my
tough seignior.

sp.speaker: Arma.
sp.p: Why tough seignior? Why tough seignior?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why tender juvenal? Why tender juvenal?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
I spoke it tender juvenal, as a congruent appellation
appertaining to thy young days, which we may nominate
tender.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
And I tough seignior, as an appertinent title to your
old time, which we may name tough.

sp.speaker: Arma.
sp.p: Pretty and apt.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
How mean you sir, I pretty, and my saying apt?
or I apt, and my saying pretty?

sp.speaker: Arma.
sp.p: Thou pretty because little.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Little pretty, because little: wherefore apt.

sp.speaker: Arma.
sp.p: And therefore apt, because quick.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Speak you this in my praise Master?

sp.speaker: Arma.
sp.p: In thy condign praise.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will praise an Eel with the same praise.

sp.speaker: Arma.
sp.p: What? that an Eel is ingenious.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That an Eel is quick.

sp.speaker: Arma.
sp.p:
I do say thou art quick in answers. Thou heatest
my blood.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I am answered sir.

sp.speaker: Arma.
sp.p: I love not to be crossed.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He speaks the mere contrary, crosses love not him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: I have promised to study three years with the duke.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You may do it in an hour sir.

sp.speaker: Arma.
sp.p: Impossible.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: How many is one thrice told?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: I am ill at reckoning, it fitteth the spirit of a Tapster.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You are a Gentleman and a Gamester sir.

sp.speaker: Arma.
sp.p:
I confess both, they are both the varnish of a complete
man.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Then I am sure you know how much the gross
sum of deuce-ace amounts to.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: It doth amount to one more than two.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Which the base vulgar do call three.

sp.speaker: Arma.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Why sir is this such a piece of study? Now here is
three studied ere you will thrice wink: and how easy it is to
put years to the word three, and study three years in two
words, the dancing Horse will tell you.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: A most fine Figure.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: To prove you a Cipher.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
I will hereupon confess I am in love: and as it is
base for a Soldier to love; so am I in love with a base wench.
If drawing my Sword against the humour of affection, would
deliver me from the reprobate thought of it, I would take
Desire prisoner, and ransom him to any French Courtier
for a new devised curtsy. I think scorn to sigh, methinks
I should outswear Cupid. Comfort me Boy, What great
men have been in love?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Hercules Master.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
Most sweet Hercules: more authority dear Boy,
name more; and sweet my child let them be men of good
repute and carriage.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Sampson Master, he was a man of good carriage,
great carriage: for he carried the Town-gates on his back
like a Porter: and he was in love.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
O well knit Sampson, strong jointed Sampson; I do excel
thee in my rapier, as much as thou didst me in carrying gates.
I am in love too. Who was Sampsons love my dear Moth?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A Woman, Master.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Of what complexion?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Of all the four, or the three, or the two, or one of
the four.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Tell me precisely of what complexion?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Of the sea-water Green sir.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Is that one of the four complexions?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: As I have read sir, and the best of them too.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
Green indeed is the colour of Lovers: but to
have a love of that colour, methinks Sampson had small
reason for it. He surely affected her for her wit.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It was so sir, for she had a green wit.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: My love is most immaculate white and red.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Most maculate thoughts Master, are masked under
such colours.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Define, define, well educated infant.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My fathers wit, and my mothers tongue assist me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Sweet invocation of a child, most pretty and pathetical.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: If she be made of white and red,
Her faults will never be known:
For blush-in cheeks by faults are bred,
And fears by pale white shown:
Then if she fear or be to blame,
By this you shall not know,
For still her cheeks possess the same,
Which native she doth owe
A dangerous rime master against the reason of white and red.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Is there not a Ballet Boy, of the King and the Beggar?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
The world was very guilty of such a Ballet some
three ages since, but I think now it is not to be found: or if it
were, it would neither serve for the writing, nor the tune.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p:
I will have that subject newly writ over, that I may
example my digression by some mighty precedent. Boy,
I do love, that Country girl that I took in the Park
with the rational hind Costard: she deserves well.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: To be whipped: and yet a better love than my master.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Sing Boy, My spirit grows heavy in love.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: And that is great marvel, loving a light Wench.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: I say sing.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Forbear till this company be past.

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p:
Sir, the Dukes pleasure is that you keep Costard
safe, and you must suffer him to take no delight, nor no penance, but he must fast three days a week: for this Damsel
I must keep her at the Park, she is allowed for the Day
womaned. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: I do betray myself with blushing: Maid.

sp.speaker: Maide.
sp.p: Man.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: I will visit thee at the Lodge.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: That is hereby.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: I know where it is situate.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Lord how wise you are.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: I will tell thee wonders.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: With that face.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: I love thee.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: So I heard you say.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: And so farewell.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Fair weather after you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Come Iaquenetta, away.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p:
Villain, thou shalt fast for thy offences ere thou be
pardoned.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Well sir I hope when I do it, I shall do it on a full
stomach.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Thou shalt be heavily punished.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I am more bound to you than your fellows, for they
are but lightly rewarded.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Take away this villain, shut him up.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Come you transgressing slave, away.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Let me not be pent up sir, I will fast being loose.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No sir, that were fast and loose: thou shalt to prison.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Well, if ever I do see the merry days of desolation
that I have seen, some shall see.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What shall some see?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Nay nothing M. Moth, but what they look upon.
It is not for prisoners to be too silent in their words, and
therefore I will say nothing: I thank God I have as little patience
as another man, and therefore I can be quiet.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
I do affect the very ground (which is base) where her
shoo (which is baser) guided by her foot (which is basest)
doth tread. I shall be forsworn (which is a great argument
of falsehood) if I love. And how can that be true love, which
is falsely attempted? Love is a familiar; Love is a Devil.
There is no evil angel but Love, yet was Sampson so tempted,
and he had an excellent strength: Yet was Salomon so
seduced, and he had a very good wit. Cupids Butshaft is too
hard for Hercules Club, and therefore too much odds for a
Spaniards Rapier: The first and second cause will not serve
my turn: the Passado he respects not, the Duella he regards
not; his disgrace is to be called Boy, but his glory is to subdue men.
Adieu Valour, rust Rapier, be still Drum, for your
manager is in love; yea he loveth. Assist me some extemporal
God of Rime, for I am sure I shall turn Sonnet. Devise
Wit, write Pen, for I am for whole volumes in folio.

div2.stage: Enter the Princesse of Fraunce, with three attending Ladies and three Lordes.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Now Madam summon up your dearest spirits,
Consider who the King your father sends:
To whom he sends, and whats his Embassy.
Yourself, held precious in the worlds esteem,
To parley with the sole inheritor
Of all perfections that a man may owe,
Matchless Nauar, the plea of no less weight,
Than Aquitaine a Dowry for a Queen.
Be now as prodigal of all Dear grace,
As Nature was in making Graces dear,
When she did starve the general world beside,
And prodigally gave them all to you.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Good L. Boyet, my beauty though but mean,
Needs not the painted flourish of your praise:
Beauty is bought by judgment of the eye,
Not uttered by base sale of chapmen's tongues:
I am less proud to hear you tell my worth,
Than you much willing to be counted wise,
In spending your Wit in the praise of mine.
But now to task the tasker, good Boyet,
You are not ignorant all telling fame
Doth noise abroad Nauar hath made a Vow,
Till painful study shall outwear three years.
No Woman may approach his silent Court:
Therefore to us seemeth it a needful course,
Before we enter his forbidden gates,
To know his pleasure, and in that behalf
Bold of your worthiness, we single you,
As our best moving fair solicitor:
Tell him, the Daughter of the King of France
On serious business craving quick dispatch,
Importuous personal conference with his grace.
Haste, signify so much while we attend,
Like humble visage Suitors his high will.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Proud of employment, willingly I go.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: All pride is willing pride, and yours is so:
Who are the Votaries my loving Lords, that are vow-fellows
with this virtuous Duke?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Longauill is one.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.l: Know you the man?

sp.speaker: 1. Lady.
sp.l: I know him Madam at a marriage feast,
Between L. Perigort and the beauteous heir
Of Iaques Fauconbridge solemnised.
In Normandie saw I this Longauill,
A man of sovereign peerless he is esteemed:
Well fitted in arts, glorious in arms:
Nothing becomes him ill that he would well.
The only soil of his fair vertues gloss,
If vertues gloss will stain with any soil,
Is a sharpe Wit matched with too blunt a Will:
Whose edge hath power to cut whose will still wills,
It should none spare, that come within his power.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Some merry mocking Lord belike, is it so?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: They say so most, that most his humours know.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Such short lived wits do wither as they grow.
Who are the rest?

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.l: The young Dumaine, a well accomplished youth,
Of all that Virtue love, for Virtue loved.
Most power to do most harm, least knowing ill:
For he hath wit to make an ill shape good,
And shape to win grace though he had no wit.
I saw him at the Duke Alansoes once,
And much too little of that good I saw,
Is my report to his great worthiness.

sp.speaker: 3. Lad.
sp.l: Another of these Students at that time,
Was there with him, if I have heard a truth.
Berowne they call him, but a merrier man,
Within the limit of becoming mirth,
I never spent an hours talk withal.
His eye begets occasion for his wit,
For every object that the one doth catch,
The other turns to a mirth-moving jest.
Which his fair tongue (conceits expositor)
Delivers in such apt and gracious words,
That aged ears play truant at his tales.
And younger hearings are quite ravished.
So sweet and voluble is his discourse.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: God bless my Ladies, are they all in love?
That every one her own hath garnished,
With such bedecking ornaments of praise.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Here comes Boyet.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Now, What admittance Lord?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Nauar had notice of your fair approach,
And he and his competitors in oath,
Were all addressed to meet you gentle Lady
Before I came: Marry thus much I have learnt,
He rather means to lodge you in the field,
Like one that comes here to besiege his Court,
Than seek a dispensation for his oath:
To let you enter his vnfellowed house.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Here comes Nauar.

sp.speaker: Nauar.
sp.l: Fair Princess, Welcome to the court of Nauar.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Fair I give you back again, and welcome I have
not yet: the roof of this Court is too high to be yours, and
welcome to the wide fields too base to be mine.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: You shall be welcome Madam to my Court.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I will be welcome then, Conduct me thither.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Hear me dear Lady, I have sworn an oath,

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Our Lady help my Lord, he will be forsworn.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Not for the world fair Madam, by my will.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Why, will shall break it will, and nothing else.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Your Ladyship is ignorant what it is.

sp.speaker: Prin,
sp.l: Were my Lord so, his ignorance were wise,
Where now his knowledge must prove ignorance.
I hear your grace hath sworn out House-keeping:
It is deadly sin to keep that oath my Lord,
And sin to break it: but pardon me, I am too sudden bold,
To teach a teacher ill beseemeth me.
Vouchsafe to read the purpose of my coming,
And suddenly resolve me in my suite.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.l: Madam I will, if suddenly I may.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: You will the sooner that I were away,
For you will prove perjured if you make me stay.

sp.speaker: Berowne.
sp.l: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

sp.speaker: Kather.
sp.l: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I know you did.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: How needles was it then to ask the question?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You must not be so quick.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: It is long of you that spur me with such questions.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Your wit is too hot, it speeds too fast, it will tire.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Not till it leave the rider in the mire.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What time a day?

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: The hour that fools should ask.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Now fair befall your mask.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Fair fall the face it covers.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: And send you many lovers.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Amen, so you be none.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Nay then will I be gon.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Madam, your father here doth intimate,
The payment of a hundred thousand Crowns,
Being but the one half of, of an entire sum,
Disbursed by my father in his wars.
But say that he, or we, as neither have
Received that sum, yet there remains unpaid
A hundred thousand more, in surety of the which,
One part of Aquitaine is bound to us,
Although not valued to the monies worth.
If then the King your father will restore,
But that one half which is unsatisfied,
We will give up our right in Aquitaine,
And hold fair friendship with his Majesty,
But that it seems he little purposeth:
For here he doth demand to have repaid,
A hundred thousand Crowns, and not demands
One payment of a hundred thousand Crowns,
To have his title live in Aquitaine.
Which we much rather had depart withal,
And have the money by our father lent,
Than Aquitaine, so gelded as it is.
Dear Princess were not his requests so far
From reasons yielding, your fair self should make
A yielding against some reason in my breast,
And go well satisfied to France again.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: You do the King my father too much wrong,
And wrong the reputation of your name,
In so unseeming to confess receipt,
Of that which hath so faithfully been paid.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I do protest I never heard of it:
And if you prove it, I will repay it back,
Or yield up Aquitaine.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.l: We arrest your word.
Boyet you can produce acquittances,
For such a sum from special officers,
Of Charles his father.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Satisfy me so.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: So please your Grace, the packet is not come,
Where that and other specialities are bound:
Tomorrow you shall have a sight of them.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: It shall suffice me; at which interview,
All liberal reason I will yield unto.
Mean time receive such welcome at my hand,
As honour (without breach of honour) may,
Make tender of to thy true worthiness.
You may not come (fair Princess) within my gates,
But here without you shall be so received,
As you shall deem yourself lodged in my heart.
Though so denied fair harbour in my house,
Your own good thoughts excuse me, and farewell.
Tomorrow shall we visit you again.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Sweet health and fair desires consort your grace.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Thy own wish wish I thee in every place.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Lady I will commend you to my none heart.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Pray you, do my commendations, I would be glad to see it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I would you heard it groan.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Is the fool sick.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sick at the heart.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Alack, let it blood.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Would that do it good?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: My Physic says Aye.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Will you prick it with your eye.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: No point, with my knife.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Now God save thy life.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: And yours from long living.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I cannot stay thanksgiving.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Sir, I pray you a word, What Lady is that same?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: The heir of Alanson, Rosalin her name.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: A gallant Lady Monsieur, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Longauill.
sp.l: I beseech you a word, What is she in the white?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: A woman sometimes, and you saw her in the light.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Perchance light in the light. I desire her name?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: She hath but one for herself, to desire that were a shame.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Pray you sir, Whose daughter?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Her mothers, I have heard.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Gods blessing on your beard.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Good sir be not offended, She is an heir of Falcon-bridge.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Nay my choler is ended. She is a most sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Not unlike sir, that may be.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Whats her name in the cap?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Katherin by good hap.

sp.speaker: Ber,
sp.l: Is she wedded or no?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: To her will sir, or so.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O you are welcome sir, adieu.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Farewell to me sir, and welcome to you.

sp.speaker: Lady Maria.
sp.l: That last is Berowne, the merry madcap L.
Not a word with him but a jest.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: And every jest but a word.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: It was well done of you to take him at his word.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I was as willing to grapple as he was to board.

sp.speaker: Lady Ka.
sp.l: Two hot Sheeps marry.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And wherefore not Ships?
No Sheep (sweet Lamb) unless we feed on your lips.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You Sheep and I pasture: shall that finish the jest?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: So you grant pasture for me.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Not so gentle Beast.
My lips are no Common, though several they be.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Belonging to whom?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: To my fortunes and me.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Good wits will be jangling, but gentles agree,
This civil war of wits were much better used
On Nauar and his Book-men, for here it is abused.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: If my observation which very seldom lies
By the heart's still rhetoric, disclosed with eyes.
Deceive me not now, Nauar is infected.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: With what?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: With that which we Lovers entitle Affected.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Your reason.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Why all his behaviours did make their retire,
To the court of his eye, peeping thorough desire.
His heart like an Agate with your print impressed,
Proud with his form, in his eye pride expressed.
His tongue all impatient to speak and not see,
Did stumble with haste in his eyesight to be,
All senses to that sense did make their repair,
To feele only looking on fairest of fair:
Methought all his senses were locked in his eye,
As Jewels in Crystal for some Prince to buy.
Who tendering their own worth from where they were glassed,
Did point you to buy them along as you past.
His faces own margent did coat such amazes,
That all eyes saw his eyes enchanted with gazes.
I will give you Aquitaine, and all that is his,
And you give him for my sake but one loving kiss.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Come, to our Pavilion, Boyet is disposed.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: But to speak that in words, which his eye hath disclosed.
I only have made a mouth of his eye,
By adding a tongue which I know will not lie.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Thou art an old Love-monger, and speakest skilfully.

sp.speaker: Lad. 2.
sp.l: He is Cupids Grandfather, and learns news
of him.

sp.speaker: Lad. 3.
sp.l: Then was Venus like her mother, for her father is
but grim.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Do you hear my mad Wenches?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: What then, do you see?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: I, our way to be gone.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You are too hard for me.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Warble child, make passionate my sense of hearing.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Concolinel.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p:
Sweet Air, go tenderness of years, take this Key,
give enlargement to the Swain, bring him festinately hither,
I must employ him in a letter to my love.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Master, will you win your love with a french brawl?

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: How meanest thou? brawling in French.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
No my complete Master, but to Jig off a tune at
the tongues end, canary to it with your feet, humour it
with turning up your eyelids, sigh a note and sing a note sometime
through the throat, if you swallowed love with singing
love sometime through: nose as if you snuffed up love by
smelling love with your hat penthouse like over the shop of
your eyes, with your arms crossed on your thin belly's doublet
like a Rabbit on a spit, or your hands in your pocket like a
man after the old painting, and keep not too long in one
tune, but a snip and away: these are complements, these
are humours, these betray nice wenches that would be betrayed without
these, and make them men of note: do you
note men that most are affected to these.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: How hast thou purchased this experience?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: By my pen of observation.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: But o but o.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The Hobbyhorse is forgot.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Callest thou my love Hobbyhorse.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
No Master, the Hobbyhorse is but a colt, and your
love perhaps, a hackney: But have you forgot your Love?

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Almost I had.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Negligent student, learn her by heart.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: By heart, and in heart boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
And out of heart Master: all those three I will
prove.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: What wilt thou prove?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
A man, if I live (and this) by, in, and without, upon the
instant: by heart you love her, because your heart cannot come
by her: in heart you love her, because your heart is in love
with her: and out of heart you love her, being out of heart
that you cannot enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: I am all these three.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
And three times as much more, and yet nothing
at all.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Fetch hither the Swain, he must carry me a letter.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
A message well sympathized, a Horse to be ambassador
for an Ass.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Ha ha, What sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Marry sir, you must send the Ass upon the Horse,
for he is very slow gated: but I go.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: The way is but short, away.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: As swift as Lead sir.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p:
The meaning pretty ingenious, is not Lead a metal
heavy, dull, and slow?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Minime honest Master, or rather Master no.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.l: I say Lead is slow.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You are too swift sir to say so.
Is that Lead slow which is fired from a Gun?

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.l: Sweet smoke of Rhetoric,
He reputes me a Cannon, and the Bullet that is he:
I shoot thee at the Swain.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Thump then, and I flee.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.l: A most acute Juvenal, voluble and free of grace,
By thy favour sweet Welkin, I must sigh in thy face:
Most rude melancholy, Valour gives thee place.
My Herald is returned.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: A wonder Master, Here is a Costard broken in a shin.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Some enigma, some riddle, come, thy L'envoy begin.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
No egma, no riddle, no lenuoy, no salve, in thee male sir.
O sir, Plantan, a pline Plantan: no lenuoy, no lenuoy, no Salve
sir, but a Plantan.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p:
By virtue thou enforcest laughter, thy silly thought,
my spleen, the heaving of my lunges provokes me to ridiculous smiling:
O pardon me my stars, doth the inconsiderate
take salve for lenuoy, and the word lenuoy for a salve?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Do the wise think them other, is not lenuoy a salve?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: No Page, it is an epilogue or discourse to make plain,
Some obscure precedence that hath tofore been said.
I will example it.
The Fox, the Ape, and the Humble-Bee,
Were still at odds being but three.
There is the moral: Now the lenuoy.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: I will add the lenuoy, say the moral again.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The Fox, the Ape, and the Humble-Bee,
Were still at odds, being but three.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: Until the Goose came out of door,
And stayed the odds by adding four.
sp.p:
Now will I begin your moral, and do you follow with
my lenuoy.
sp.l: The Fox, the Ape, and the Humble-Bee,
Were still at odds, being but three.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Until the Goose came out of door,
Staying the odds by adding four.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p:
A good Lenuoy, ending in the Goose: would you
desire more?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: The Boy hath sold him a bargain, a Goose, that is flat.
Sir, your penny-worth is good, and your Goose be fat.
To sell a bargain well is as cunning as fast and loose:
Let me see a fat Lenuoy, Aye that is a fat Goose.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Come hither, come hither: How did this argument begin?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: By saying that a Costard was broken in a shin.
sp.p: Then called you for the Lenuoy.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
True, and I for a Plantan, thus came your argument in,
Then the boy's fat Lenuoy, the Goose that you bought,
and he ended the market.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: But tell me, How was there a Costard broken in a shin?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: I will tell you sensibly.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Thou hast no feeling of it Moth, I will speak that Lenuoy.
sp.l: I Costard running out, that was safely within,
Fell over the threshold, and broke my shin.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: We will talk no more of this matter.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Till there be more matter in the shin.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Sirrah Costard, I will enfranchise thee.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
O marry me to one Francis, I smell some Lenuoy,
some Goose in this.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
By my sweet soul, I mean, setting thee at liberty.
Enfreedoming thy person: thou wert immured, restrained,
captivated, bound.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p:
True, true, and now you will be my purgation,
and let me loose.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p:
I give thee thy liberty, set thee from durance, and in
lieu thereof, impose on thee nothing but this: Bear this
significant to the country Maid Iaquenetta: there is remuneration,
for the best ward of mine honour, is rewarding
my dependants. Moth, follow.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Like the sequel I. Seignior Costard adieu.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
My sweet ounce of man's flesh, my in-cony Jew:
Now will I look to his remuneration.
Remuneration, O that is the latin word for three-farthings:
Three-farthings remuration, What is the price of this uncle?
i.d. no, I will give you a remuneration: Why? it carries it remuneration:
Why? it is a fairer name then french crown.
I will never buy and sell out of this word.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: O my good knave Costard, exceedingly well met.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Pray you sir, How much Carnation Ribbon may
a man buy for a remuneration?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: O what is a remuneration?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: Marry sir, halfpenny farthing.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: O, why then three farthing worth of Silk.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: I thank your worship, God be with you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O stay slave, I must employ thee.
As thou wilt win my favour, good my knave,
Do one thing for me that I shall entreat.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: When would you have it done sir?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Well, I will do it sir: Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O thou knowest not what it is.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I shall know sir when I have done it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why villain, thou must know first.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I will come to your worship tomorrow morning.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: It must be done this after noon,
Hark slave, it is but this:
The Princess comes to hunt here in the Park,
And in her train there is a gentle Lady:
When tongues speak sweetly, then they name her name,
And Rosaline they call her, ask for her:
And to her white hand see thou do commend
This sealed-up counsel. There is thy guerdon: go.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Gardon, O sweet gardon, better than remuneration.
a elevenpence-farthing better: most sweet gardon. I will
do it sir in print: gardon remuneration.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O and I forsooth in love, I that have been loves whip?
A very Beadle to a humorous sigh, a Critic, nay a nightwatch Constable,
A domineering pedant over the Boy, then whom no mortal
so magnificent.
This wimpled whining purblind wayward Boy,
This seignior Iunios giant dwarf, dan Cupid,
Regent of Love-rimes, Lord of folded arms,
The anointed sovereign of sighs and groans:
Liege of all loiterers and malcontents:
Dread Prince of Placates, King of Codpieces.
Sole Imperator and great general
Of trotting Parrators (O my little heart.)
And I to be a Corporal of his field,
And wear his colours like a Tumblers hoop.
What? I love, I sue, I seek a wife,
A woman that is like a German Clock,
Still a repairing: ever out of frame,
And never going aright, being a Watch:
But being watched, that it may still go right.
Nay to be perjured, which is worst of all:
And among three to love the worst of all,
A whitely wanton, with a velvet brow,
With two pitch balls stuck in her face for eyes.
Aye and by heaven, one that will do the deed,
Though Argus were her eunuch and her guard.
And I to sigh for her, to watch for her,
To pray for her, go to: it is a plague
That Cupid will impose for my neglect,
Of his almighty dreadful little might.
Well, I will love, write, sigh, pray, sue, groan,
Some men must love my Lady, and some Ione.

div2.stage: Enter the Princesse, a Forrester, her Ladyes, and her Lordes

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Was that the king that spurred his horse so hard,
Against the steep up rising of the hill?

sp.speaker: Forr.
sp.l: I know not, but I think it was not he.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Whoever he was, a showed a mounting mind.
Well Lords, today we shall have our dispatch,
Over Saturday we will return to Fraunce.
Then Forester my friend, Where is the Bush
That we must stand and play the murtherer in?

sp.speaker: Forr.
sp.l: Hereby upon the edge of yonder Coppice,
A Stand where you may make the fairest shoot.

sp.speaker: Qnee.
sp.l: I thank my Beauty, I am fair that shoot,
And thereupon thou speakest the fairest shoot.

sp.speaker: Forr.
sp.l: Pardon me Madam, for I meant not so.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: What, what? First praise me, and again say no.
O short lived pride. Not fair? alack for woe

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Yes Madam fair.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Nay, never paint me now,
Where fair is not, praise cannot mend the brow.
Here (good my glass) take this for telling true:
Fair payment for foul words, is more than dew.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Nothing but fair is that which you inherit.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: See see, my beauty will be saved by merit.
O heresy in fair, fit for these days,
A giving hand, though foul, shall have fair praise.
But come, the Bow: Now Mercy goes to kill,
And shooting well, is then accounted ill:
Thus will I save my Credit in the shoot,
Not wounding, pity would not let me do it.
If wounding then it was to show my skill,
That more for praise, than purpose meant to kill.
And out of question so it is sometimes:
Glory grows guilty of detested crimes,
When for Fames sake, for praise an outward part,
We bend to that, the working of the heart.
As I for praise alone now seek to spill
The poor Deer's blood, that my heart means no ill.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Do not cursed wives hold that self-sovereignty
Only for praise sake, when they strive to be
Lords over their Lords?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Only for praise, and praise we may afford,
To any Lady that subdues a Lord.

sp.speaker: Boyet,
sp.l: Here comes a member of the common wealth.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: God dig-you-den all, pray you which is the head lady?

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.p: Thou shalt know her fellow by the rest that have no heads.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Which is the greatest Lady, the highest?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: The thickest, and the tallest.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: The thickest, and the tallest: it is so, truth is truth.
If your waist Mistress were as slender as my wit,
One of these Maids girdles for your waist should be fit.
Are not you the chief woman? You are the thickest here.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Whats your will sir? Whats your will?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
I have a Letter from Monsieur Berowne,
to one Lady Rosaline.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: O thy letter, thy letter: He is a good friend of mine.
Stand aside good bearer. Boyet you can carve,
Break up this Capon.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: I am bound to serve.
This letter is mistook: it importeth none here.
It is writ to Iaquenetta.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: We will read it, I swear.
Break the neck of the Wax, and everyone give ear.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.p:
BY heaven, that thou art fair, is most infallible:
true that thou art beauteous, truth itself that
thou art lovely: more fairer than fair, beautiful than beauteous,
truer than truth itself: have commiseration on thy
heroical Vassal. The magnanimous and most illustrate
King Cophetua set eye upon the pernicious and indubitate
Beggar Zenelophon: and he it was that might rightly say,
Veni, vidi, vici: Which to annothanize in the vulgar, O base
and obscure vulgar; videliset, He came, See, and overcame:
He came, one; see, two; overcame, three. Who came? the
King. Why did he come? to see. Why did he see? to overcome.
To whom came he? to the Beggar. What saw he? the
Beggar. Who overcame he? the Beggar. The conclusion is
victory: On whose side? the King: the captive is enriched, on
whose side? the Beggars. The catastrophe is a Nuptial, on
whose side? the Kings: no, on both in one, or one in both.
I am the King (for so stands the comparison) thou the Beggar,
for so witnesseth thy lowliness. Shall I command thy
love? I may. Shall I enforce thy love? I could. Shall I entreat
thy love? I will. What, shalt thou exchange for rags
robes, for tittles titles, for thyself, me. Thus expecting
thy reply, I profane my lips on thy foot, my eyes on
thy picture, and my heart on thy every part.
Thine in the dearest design of industry,
Don Adriana de Armatho.

Thus dost thou hear the nemean Lion roar,
Against thee thou Lamb, that standest as his prey:
Submissive fall his princely feet before,
And he from forage will incline to play.
But if thou strive (poor soul) what art thou then?
Food for his rage, repasture for his den.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: What plume of feathers is he that indicted this letter?
What vain? What Weathercock? Did you ever hear better?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I am much deceived, but I remember the style.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Else your memory is bad, going over it erewhile.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: This Armado is a Spaniard that keeps here in court,
A Phantasm a Monarcho, and one that makes sport
To the Prince and his Book-mates.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Thou fellow, a word.
Who gave thee this letter?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: I told you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: To whom shouldst thou give it?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: From my Lord to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: From which Lord, to which Lady?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: From my Lord Berowne, a good Master of mine,
To a Lady of France, that he called Rosaline.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Thou hast mistaken his letter. Come Lords away.
Here sweet, put up this, it will be thine another day.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Who is the shooter? Who is the shooter?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Shall I teach you to know.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Aye my continent of beauty.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Why she that bears the Bow. Finely put off.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
My Lady goes to kill horns, but if thou marry,
hang me by the neck, if horns that year miscarry.
Finely put on.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Well then I am the shooter.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: And who is your Dear?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p:
If we choose by the horns, yourself come not
near. Finely put on indeed.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p:
You still wrangle with her Boyet, and she strikes
at the brow.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p: But she herself is hit lower: Have I hit her now?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p:
Shall I come upon thee with an old saying, that
was a man when King Pippen of France was a little boy, as
touching the hit it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
So I may answer thee with one as old that was a
woman when queen Guinouer of Britain was a little wench
as touching the hit it.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Thou canst not hit it, hit it, hit it,
Thou canst not hit it my good man.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: And I cannot, cannot, cannot: and I cannot, another can,

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: By my troth most pleasant, how both did fit it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A mark marvelous well shot, for they both did hit.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: A mark, O mark but that mark: a mark says my Lady.
Let the mark have a prick in it, to meat at, if it may be.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Wide at the bow hand, i'faith your hand is out.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Indeed he must shoot nearer, or he will never hit the clout.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: And if my hand be out, then belike your hand is in.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Then will she get the upshoot by cleaving the is in.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Come come, you talk greasily, your lips grow foul.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: She is too hard for you at pricks, sir challenge her to bowl

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I fear too much rubbing: good night my good owl.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: By my soul a Swain, a most simple Clown.
Lord, Lord, how the Ladies and I have put him down.
O my troth most sweet jests, most iconic vulgar wit,
When it comes so smoothly off, so obscenely as it were, so fit.
Armatho hath totem side, o a most dainty man,
To see him walk before a Lady, and to bear her Fan.
To see him kiss his hand, and how most sweetly he will swear:
And his Page at the other side, that handful of wit,
Ah heavens, it is most pathetical nit.
Sola, Sola.

div2.stage: Enter Dull, Holofernes, the Pedant and Nathaniel.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.p:
Very reverent sport truly, and done in the testimony
of a good conscience.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
The Dear was (as you know) sanguis in blood, ripe
as the Pomewater, who now hangeth like a Jewel in the ear
of Celo the sky, the welkin the heaven, and anon falleth like
a Crab on the face of Terra, the soil, the land, the earth.

sp.speaker: Curat Nath.
sp.p:
Truly M. Holofernes, the epithets are
sweetly varied like a scholar at the least: but sir I assure ye
it was a Buck of the first head.

sp.speaker: Holo.
sp.p: Sir Nathaniel, haud credo.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: It was not a haud credo, it was a Pricket.

sp.speaker: Holo.
sp.p:
Most barbarous intimation: yet a kind of insinuation,
as it were in via, in way of explication facere: as it were
replication, or rather ostentare, to show as it were his inclination
after his undressed, unpolished, uneducated, unpruned,
untrained, or rather unlettered, or ratherest unconfirmed fashion,
to insert again my haud credo for a Dear.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: I said the Dear was not a haud credo, it was a Pricket.

sp.speaker: Holo.
sp.p:
Twice sod simplicity, bis coctus, O thou monster
ignorance, How deformed dost thou look.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
Sir he hath never fed of the dainties that are bred
in a book.
He hath not eat paper as it were: he hath not drunk ink.
His intellect is not replenished, he is only an animal, only
sensible in the duller parts: and such barren plants are
set before us, that we thankful should be: which we taste,
and feeling, are for those parts that do fructify in us
more than he.
For as it would ill become me to be vain, indiscreet, or a fool,
So were there a patch set on Learning, to see him in a school.
But omne bene say I, being of an old Fathers mind,
Many can brooke the weather, that love not the wind.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p:
You two are book-men, Can you tell me by your wit,
What was a month old at Cains birth, that is not five weeks
old as yet?

sp.speaker: Holo.
sp.p: Dictisima goodman Dull, dictisima goodman Dull.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: What is dictima?

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p: A title to Phebe, to Luna, to the Moon.

sp.speaker: Holo.
sp.l: The Moon was a month old when Adam was no more
And wrought not to five-weeks when he came to fivescore.
The allusion holds in the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: It is true indeed, the Collusion holds in the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Holo.
sp.p:
God comfort thy capacity, I say the allusion holds
in the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p:
And I say the polusion holds in the Exchange: for
the Moon is never but a month old: and I say beside
that, it was a Pricket that the Princess killed.

sp.speaker: Holo.
sp.p:
Sir Nathaniel, will you hear an extemporal Epitaph
on the death of the Dear, and to humour the ignorant
called the Dear: the Princess killed a Pricket.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
Perge, good M. Holofernes perge, so it shall please
you to abrogate scurrility.

sp.speaker: Holo.
sp.p:
I will something affect the letter, for it argues facility.
The prayful Princess pierced and pricked
a pretty pleasing Pricket,
Some say a Sore, but not a sore,
till now made sore with shooting.
The Dogs did yell, put ell to Sore,
then Sorrel jumps from thicket:
Or Pricket-sore, or else Sorrel,
the people fall ahooting.
If Sore be sore, then el to Sore,
makes fifty sores o sorrel:
Of one sore I an hundred make
by adding but one more l.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p: A rare talent.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p:
If a talent be a claw, look how he claws him
with a talent.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
This is a gift that I have simple: simple, a foolish
extravagant spirit, full of forms, figures, shapes, objects,
Ideas, apprehensions, motions, revolutions. These are begot in
the ventricle of Memory, nourished in the womb of pia mater,
and delivered upon the mellowing of occasion: But the
gift is good in those whom it is acute, and I am thankful
for it.

sp.speaker: Holo.
sp.p:
Sir, I praise the L. for you, and so may my parishioners,
for their Sons are well tutored by you, and their
Daughters profit very greatly under you: you are a good
member of the common wealth.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
Me hercle, if their Sons be ingenious, they shall
want no instruction: If their Daughters be capable, I will
put it to them. But Vir sapis qui pauca loquitur, a soul Feminine
saluteth us.

sp.speaker: Iaquenetta
sp.p: God give you good morrow M. Person.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
Master Person, quasi Person? And if one should
be pierced, Which is the one?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Marry M. Schoolmaster, he that is likeliest to a hogshead.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
Of piercing a Hogshead, a good luster of conceit
in a turf of Earth, Fire enough for a Flint, Pearl enough
for a Swine: it is pretty, it is well.

sp.speaker: Iaque.
sp.p:
Good M. Parson be so good as read me this letter,
it was given me by Costard, and sent me from Don Armatho:
I beseech you read it.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
Facile precor gellida, quando pecas omnia sub vmbra ruminat,
and so forth. Ah good old Mantuan, I may speak
of thee as the traveller doth of Venice, vemchie, vencha, que non
te vnde, que non te perreche. Old Mantuan, old Mantuan,
Who uvnderstandeth thee not, loves thee not, vt re sol la mi fa:
Under pardon sir, What are the contents? or rather as Horrace
says in his, What my soul verses.

sp.speaker: Holo.
sp.p: Aye sir, and very learned.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p: Let me hear a staff, a stanza, a verse, Lege domine.

sp.l: If Love make me forsworn, how shall I swear to love?
Ah never faith could hold, if not to beauty vowed.
Though to myself forsworn, to thee I will faithful prove.
Those thoughts to me were Oaks, to thee like Osiers bowed
Study his bias leaves, and makes his book thine eyes.
Where all those pleasures live, that Art would comprehend.
If knowledge be the mark, to know thee shall suffice.
Well learned is that tongue, that well can thee commend.
All ignorant that soul, that sees thee without wonder.
Which is to me some praise, that I thy parts admire,
Thy eye Ioues lightning bears, thy voice his dreadful thunder
Which not to anger bent, is music, and sweet fire.
Celestial as thou art, O pardon love this wrong,
That singes heavens praise, with such an earthly tong.

sp.speaker: Pedan.
sp.p:
You find not the apostrophes, and so miss the
accent. Let me supervise the canzonet.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
Here are only numbers ratified, but for the elegancy,
facility, and golden cadence of poesy caret: Ouiddius
Naso was the man. And why indeed Naso, but for smelling
out the odoriferous flowers of fancy? the jerks of invention
imitari is nothing: So doth the Hound his master,
the Ape his keeper, the tired Horse his rider: But Damosella
virgin, Was this directed to you?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
Aye sir from one monsieur Berowne, one of the strange
Queens Lords.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
I will overglanced the superscript.
To the snow-white hand of the most beauteous Lady Rosaline.
I will look again on the intellect of the letter, for the nomination
of the party written to the person written unto.
Your Ladyships in all desired employment, Berowne.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
Sir Holofernes, this Berowne is one of the Votaries
with the King, and here he hath framed a letter to a sequent
of the stranger Queens: which accidentally, or by the way
of progression, hath miscarried. Trip and go my sweet,
deliver this Paper into the royal hand of the King, it may
concern much: stay not thy complement, I forgive thy
duty, adieu.

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.p: Good Costard go with me: sir God save your life.

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: Have with thee my girl.

sp.speaker: Holo.
sp.p:
Sir you have done this in the fear of God very religiously:
and as a certain Father saith

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
Sir tell not me of the Father, I do fear colourable
colours. But to return to the Verses, Did they please you
sir Nathaniel?

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p: Marvelous well for the pen.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p:
I do dine today at the fathers of a certain pupil of
mine, where if (before repast) it shall please you to gratify
the table with a Grace, I will on my privilege I have with
the parents of the foresaid child or pupil, undertake your
bien venuto, where I will prove those Verses to be very unlearned,
neither savouring of Poetry, wit, nor invention.
I beseech your society.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p:
And thank you too: for society (saith the text)
is the happiness of life.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p:
And certes the text most infallibly concludes it.
Sir I do invite you too, you shall not say me nay: pauca verba.
Away, the gentles are at their game, and we will to our recreation.

div2.stage: Enter Berowne with a paper in his hand, alone.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.p:
The King he is hunting the Dear,
I am coursing myself.
They have pitched a Toil, I am toiling in a pitch, pitch
that defiles; defile, a foul word: Well, set thee down
sorrow; for so they say the fool said, and so say I, and I the
fool: Well proved wit. By the Lord this Love is as mad
as Aiax, it kills Sheep, it kills me, I a Sheep well proved
again a my side. I will not love; if I do hang me: I'faith
I will not. O but her eye: by this light, but for her eye, I
would not love her; yes for her two eyes. Well, I do nothing
in the world but lie, and lie in my throat. By heaven I do
love, and it hath taught me to rime, and to be melancholy:
and here is part of my Rime, and hear my melancholy.
Well, she hath one of my Sonnets already, the Clown bore
it, the Fool sent it, and the Lady hath it: sweet Clown,
sweeter Fool, sweetest Lady. By the world, I would not
care a pin, if the other three were in. Here comes one with
a paper, God give him grace to groan.

div2.stage: He standes a side.The King entreth.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Aye me!

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p:
Shot by heaven, proceed sweet Cupid, thou hast thumped
him with thy Bird-bolt under the left pap: in faith secrets.

sp.speaker: King,
sp.l: So sweet a kiss the golden Sun gives not,
To those fresh morning drops upon the Rose,
As thy eye beams, when their fresh rays have smote.
The night of dew that on my cheeks down flows,
Nor shines the silver Moon one half so bright,
Through the transparent bosom of the deep,
As doth thy face through tears of mine give light:
Thou shinest in every tear that I do weep,
No drop but as a Coach doth carry thee:
So ridest thou triumphing in my woe.
Do but behold the tears that swell in me,
And they thy glory through my grief will show:
But do not love thyself, then thou will keep
My tears for glasses, and still make me weep.
O Queen of queens, how far dost thou excel,
No thought can think, nor tongue of mortal tell.
How shall she know my griefs? I will drop the paper.
Sweet leaves shade folly. Who is he comes here?
sp.stage: Enter Longauill. The King steps a side.
sp.l: What Longauill, and reading: listen ear.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.p: Now in thy likeness, one more fool appear.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Aye me! I am forsworn.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: Why he comes in like a perjure, wearing papers.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: In love I hope, sweet fellowship in shame.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: One drunkard loves another of the name.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Am I the first that have been perjured so?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I could put thee in comfort, not by two that I know,
Thou makest the triumphery, the corner cap of society,
The shape of Loves Tiburne, that hangs up Simplicity.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I fear these stubborn lines lack power to move.
O sweet Maria, Empress of my Love,
These numbers will I tear, and write in prose.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O Rimes are guards on wanton Cupids hose,
Disfigure not his Shop.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: This same shall go.
Did not the heavenly Rhetoric of thine eye,
Against whom the world cannot hold argument,
Persuade my heart to this false perjury?
Vows for thee broke deserve not punishment.
A Woman I forswore, but I will prove,
Thou being a Goddess, I forswore not thee.
My Vow was earthly, thou a heavenly Love.
Thy grace being gained, cures all disgrace in me.
Vows are but breath, and breath a vapour is.
Then thou fair Sun, which on my earth dost shine,
Exhalest this vapour-vow in thee it is:
If broken then, it is no fault of mine:
If by me broke, What fool is not so wise,
To lose an oath, to win a Paradise?

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: This is the liver vein, which makes flesh a deity.
A green Goose, a Goddess, pure pure idolatory.
God amend us, God amend, we are much out of the way.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: By whom shall I send this (company?) Stay.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: All hid, all hid, an old infant play,
Like a demi God, here sit I in the sky,
And wretched fools secrets heedfully over eye.
More Sacks to the mill. O heavens I have my wish,
Dumaine transformed, four Woodcocks in a dish.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: O most divine Kate.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: O most profane coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: By heaven the wonder in a mortal eye.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: By earth she is not, corporal, there you lie.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: Her Amber heirs for foul hath amber coated.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: An amber coloured Raven was well noted.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: As upright as the Cedar.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Stoop I say, her shoulder is with child.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: As fair as day.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Aye as some days, but then no Sun must shine.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: O that I had my wish?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And I had mine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And mine too good Lord.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Amen, so I had mine: Is not that a good word?

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: I would forget her, but a Fever she
Reigns in my blood, and will remembered be.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: A Fever in your blood, why then incision
Would let her out in Saucers, sweet misprison.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Once more I will read the Ode that I have writ.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Once more I will mark how Love can vary Wit.
On a day, alack the day:
Love, whose Month is ever May:
Spied a blossom passing fair,
Playing in the wanton air:
Through the Velvet, leaves the wind,
All unseen, can passage find:
That the Lover sick to death,
Wish himself the heavens breath.
Air (quoth he) thy cheeks may blow,
Air would I might triumph so.
But alack my hand is sworn,
Never to pluck thee from thy throne:
Vow alack for youth unmeet,
Youth so apt to pluck a sweet.
Do not call it sin in me,
That I am forsworn for thee:
Thou for whom Ioue would swear,
Iuno but an Aethiop were,
And deny himself for Ioue,
Turning mortal for thy love.
This will I send, and something else more plain.
That shall express my true loves fasting pain.
O would the King, Berowne, and Longauill,
Were Lovers too, ill to example ill,
Would from my forehead wipe a perjured note:
For none offend, where all alike do dote.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Dumaine thy Love is far from charity,
That in loves grief desirest society:
You may look pale, but I should blush I know,
To be overheard and taken napping so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come sir, you blush: as his, your case is such.
You chide at him, offending twice as much.
You do not love Maria? Longauile,
Did never Sonnet for her sake compile,
Nor never lay his wreathed arms athwart
His loving bosom, to keep down his heart.
I have been closely shrouded in this bush,
And marked you both, and for you both did blush.
I heard your guilty Rimes, observed your fashion:
Saw sighs reek from you, noted well your passion.
Aye me says one! O Ioue the other cries!
One her hairs were Gold, Crystal the others eyes.
You would for Paradise break Faith and troth,
And Ioue for your Love would infringe an oath.
What will Berowne say when that he shall hear
Faith infringed, which such zeal did swear.
How will he scorn, how will he spend his wit?
How will he triumph, leap, and laugh at it?
For all the wealth that ever I did see,
I would not have him know so much by me.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Now step I forth to whip hypocrisy.
Ah good my Liege, I pray thee pardon me.
Good heart, What grace hast thou thus to reprove
These Worms for loving, that art most in love?
Your eyes do make no couches in your tears.
There is no certain Princess that appears.
You will not be perjured, it is a hateful thing:
Tush, none but Minstrels like of Sonnetting.
But are you not ashamed? nay, are you not
All three of you, to be thus much overshot?
You found his Moth, the King your Moth did see:
But I a Beam do find in each of three.
O what a Scene of foolery have I seen,
Of sighs, of groans, of sorrow, and of teen:
O me, with what strict patience have I sat,
To see a King transformed to a Gnat.
To see great Hercules whipping a Gigue,
And profound Sallomon to tune a Jig.
And Nestor play at push-pin with the boys,
And Critic Tymon laugh at idle toys.
Where lies thy grief, o tell me good Dumaine?
And gentle Longauill, where lies thy pain?
And where my Lieges? all about the breast.
A Caudle ho!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Too bitter is thy jest.
Are we betrayed thus to thy over-view?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Not you by me, but I betrayed to you.
I that am honest, I that hold it sin
To break the vow I am engaged in.
I am betrayed by keeping company
With men like men of inconstancy.
When shall you see me write a thing in rime?
Or groan for Ione? or spend a minutes time,
In pruning me when shall you hear that I will praise a
hand, a foot, a face, an eye: a gate, a state, a brow, a breast,
a waist, a leg, a limb.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Soft, Whither a way so fast?
A true man, or a thief, that gallops so.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I post from Love, good Lover let me go.

sp.speaker: Iaqu.
sp.p: God bless the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What present hast thou there?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Some certain treason.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What makes treason here?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Nay it makes nothing sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: If it mar nothing neither,
The treason and you go in peace away together.

sp.speaker: Iaque.
sp.l: I beseech your Grace let this Letter be read,
Our person misdoubts it: it was treason he said.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Berowne read it over.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where hadst thou it?

sp.speaker: Iaqu.
sp.p: Of Costard.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where hadst thou it?

sp.speaker: Cost.
sp.p: Of Dun Adramadio, Dun Adramadio.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: How now, What is in you? Why dost thou tear it?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: A toy my Liege, a toy: your grace needs not fear it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: It did move him to passion, and therefore let us hear it.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: It is Berownes writing, and here is his name.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.p:
Ah you whoreson loggerhead, you were born to
do me shame.
sp.l: Guilty my Lord, guilty: I confess, I confess.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: That you three fools, lacked me fool, to make up the mess.
He, he, and you: and you my Liege, and I,
Are pick-purses in Love, and we deserve to die.
O dismiss this audience, and I shall tell you more.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: Now the number is even.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: True true, we are four: will these turtles be gon?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hence sirs, away.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Walk aside the true folk, and let the traitors stay.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sweet Lords, sweet Lovers, O let us embrace,
As true we are as flesh and blood can be,
The Sea will ebb and flow, heaven show his face:
Young blood doth not obey an old decree.
We cannot cross the cause why we were born:
Therefore of all hands must we be forsworn.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What, did these rent lines show some love of thine?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Did they quoth you? Who sees the heavenly Rosaline,
That (like a rude and savage man of Inde.)
At the first opening of the gorgeous East,
Bows not his vassal head, and strucken blind.
Kisses the base ground with obedient breast.
What peremptorily Eagle-sighted eye
Dares look upon the heaven of her brow,
That is not blinded by her majesty?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What zeal, what fury, hath inspired thee now?
My Love (her Mistress) is a gracious Moon,
She (an attending Star) scarce seen a light.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My eyes are then no eyes, nor I Berowne.
O, but for my Love, day would turn to night,
Of all complexions the culled sovereignty,
Do meet as at a fair in her fair cheek,
Where several worthies make one dignity,
Where nothing wants, that want itself doth seek.
Lend me the flourish of all gentle tongues,
Fie painted Rhetoric, O she needs it not,
To things of sale, a sellers praise belongs:
She passes praise, then praise too short doth blot.
A withered Hermit fivescore winters worn,
Might shake off fifty, looking in her eye:
Beauty doth varnish Age, as if new born,
And gives the Crutch the Cradles infancy.
O it is the Sun that maketh all things shine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: By heaven, thy Love is black as Ebony.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: Is Ebony like her? O word divine!
A wife of such wood were felicity.
O who can give an oath? Where is a book?
That I may swear Beauty doth beauty lack,
If that she learn not of her eye to look:
No face is fair that is not full so black.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O paradox, Black is the badge of Hell,
The hue of dungeons, and the School of night:
And beauties crest becomes the heavens well.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Devils soonest tempt resembling spirits of light.
O if in black my Ladies brows be decked,
It mourns, that painting usurping hair
Should ravish doters with a false aspect:
And therefore is she born to make black fair.
Her favour turns the fashion of the days,
For native blood is counted painting now:
And therefore red that would avoid dispraise,
Paints itself black, to imitate her brow.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: To look like her are Chimney-sweepers blake.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And since her time are Colliers counted bright.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And Aethiops of their sweet complexion crake.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: Dark needs no Candles now, for dark is light.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Your Mistresses dare never come in rain,
For fear their colours should be washed away.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It were good yours did: for sir to tell you plain,
I will find a fairer face not washed today.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I will prove her fair, or talk till doomsday here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No Devil will fright thee then so much as she.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: I never knew man hold vile stuff so dear.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Look, here is thy love, my foot and her face see.

sp.speaker: Ber
sp.l: O if the streets were paved with thine eyes,
Her feet were much too dainty for such tread.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: O vile, then as she goes what upward lies?
The street should see as she walked over head.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But what of this, are we not all in love?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O nothing so sure, and thereby all forsworn.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then leave this chat, and good Berowne now prove
Our loving lawful, and our faith not torn.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: Aye marry there, some flattery for this evil.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: O some authority how to proceed,
Some tricks, some quillets, how to cheat the devil.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: Some salve for perjury.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O it is more than need.
Have at you then affections men at arms,
Consider what you first did swear unto:
To fast, to study, and to see no woman:
Flat treason against the kingly state of youth.
Say, Can you fast? your stomachs are too young:
And abstinence engenders maladies.
And where that you have vowed to study (Lords)
In that each of you have forsworn his Book.
Can you still dream and pore and thereon look.
For when would you my Lord, or you, or you,
