Have found the ground of Studies excellence,
Without the beauty of a woman's face?
From women's eyes this doctrine I derive,
They are the Ground, the Books, the Academies,
From whence doth spring the true Promethean fire.
Why universal plodding poisons up
The nimble spirits in the arteries,
As motion and long during action tires
The sinewy vigour of the traveller.
Now for not looking on a woman's face,
You have in that forsworn the use of eyes:
And study too, the causer of your vow.
For where is any Author in the world,
Teaches such beauty as a womans eye:
Learning is but an adjunct to ourself,
And where we are, our Learning likewise is.
Then when ourselves we see in Ladies eyes,
With ourselves.
Do we not likewise see our learning there?
O we have made a Vow to study, Lords,
And in that Vow we have forsworn our Books:
For when would you (my Liege) or you, or you?
In leaden contemplation have found out
Such fiery Numbers as the prompting eyes,
Of beauty's tutors have enriched you with:
Other slow Arts entirely keep the brain:
And therefore finding barren practisers,
Scarce show a harvest of their heavy toil.
But Love first learned in a Ladies eyes,
Lives not alone immured in the brain:
But with the motion of all elements,
Courses as swift as thought in every power,
And gives to every power a double power,
Above their functions and their offices.
It adds a precious seeing to the eye:
A Lovers eyes will gaze an Eagle blind.
A Lovers ear will hear the lowest sound.
When the suspicious head of theft is stopped.
Loves feeling is more soft and sensible,
Than are the tender horns of Cockled Snails.
Loves tongue proves dainty, Bachus gross in taste,
For Valour, is not Love a Hercules?
Still climbing trees in the Hesperides.
Subtle as Sphinx, as sweet and musical,
As bright Appolos Lute, strung with his hair.
And when Love speaks, the voice of all the Goddess,
Make heaven drowsy with the harmony.
Never durst Poet touch a pen to write,
Until his Ink were tempered with Loves sighs:
O then his lines would ravish savage ears,
And plant in Tyrants mild humility.
From women's eyes this doctrine I derive.
They sparkle still the right promethean fire,
They are the Books, the Arts, the Academies,
That show, contain, and nourish all the world.
Else none at all in aught proves excellent.
Then fools you were, these women to forswear:
Or keeping what is sworn, you will prove fools,
For Wisdom's sake, a word that all men love:
Or for Loves sake, a word that loves all men.
Or for Men's sake, the author of these Women:
Or Women's sake, by whom we Men are Men.
Let us once lose our oaths to find ourselves,
Or else we lose ourselves, to keep our oaths:
It is Religion to be thus forsworn.
For Charity itself fulfils the Law:
And who can sever Love from Charity.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Saint Cupid then and Soldiers to the field.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: Advance your standards, and upon them Lords.
Pell, mell, down with them: but be first advised,
In conflict that you get the Sun of them.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Now to plain dealing. Lay these glosses by,
Shall we resolve to woe these girls of Fraunce?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And win them too, therefore let us devise,
Some entertainment for them in their Tents.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: First from the Park let us conduct them thither,
Then homeward every man attach the hand
Of his fair Mistress, in the afternoon
We will with some strange pastime solace them:
Such as the shortness of the time can shape,
For Revels, Dances, Masks, and merry hours,
Forerun fair Love, strewing her way with flowers.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Away, away, no time shall be omitted,
That will be time and may by us befitted.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Alone alone sowed Cockle, reaped no Corn,
And Justice always whirls in equal measure:
Light Wenches may prove plagues to men forsworn,
If so our Copper byes no better treasure.

div2.stage: Enter the Pedant, the Curat, and Dull.

sp.speaker: Pedant.
sp.p: Satis quid sufficit.

sp.speaker: Curat.
sp.p:
I praise God for you sir, your reasons at Dinner
have been sharpe and sententious: pleasant without scurrility,
witty without affection, audacious without impudency,
learned without opinion, and strange without heresy: I did
converse this quondam day with a companion of the kings,
who is entitled, nominated, or called, Don Adriano de Armatho.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
Noui hominum tanquam te, His humour is lofty, his
discourse peremptory: his tongue filed, his eye ambitious,
his gait majestical, and his general behaviour vain, ridiculous,
and thrasonicall. He is too picked, too spruce, too affected,
too odd as it were, too peregrinatory as I may call it.

sp.speaker: Curat.
sp.p: A most singular and choice Epithet,

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p:
He draweth out the thread of his verbosity, finer
than the staple of his argument. I abhor such fanatical
phantasms, such unsociable and point devise companions,
such rackers of orthography, as to speak dout fine, when he
should say doubt; det, when he should pronounce debt; d e b t,
not det: he clepeth a Calf, Caufe: half, haufe: neighbour
vocatur nebour; neigh abreviated ne: this is abominable,
which he would call abominable, it insinuateth me of infamy:
ne inteligis domine, to make frantic lunatic?

sp.speaker: Curat.
sp.p: Laus deo, bene intelligo.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: Bome boon for boon prescian, a little scratched, it will serve.

sp.speaker: Curat.
sp.p: Vides ne quis venit?

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: Video, et gaudio.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Chirra.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: Quari Chirra, not Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Men of peace well encountered.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Most military sir salutation.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
They have been at a great feast of Languages, and
stolen the scraps.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
O they have lived long on the alms-basket of words.
I marvel thy M. hath not eaten thee for a word, for thou
art not so long by the head as honorificabilitudinitatibus:
Thou art easier swallowed than a flapdragon.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Peace, the peal begins.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Monsieur, are you not lettered?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Yes yes, he teaches boys the Hornbook: What
is Ab spelled backward with the horn on his head?

sp.speaker: Poda.
sp.p: Ba, puericia with a horn added.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Ba most silly Sheep, with a horn: you hear his learning.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: Quis quis thou Consonant?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p:
The last of the five Vowels if You repeat them,
or the fifth if I.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: I will repeat them: a e I.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: The Sheep, the other two concludes it o u.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p:
Now by the salt wane of the meditaranium, a
sweet touch, a quick venue of wit, snip snap, quick and
home, it rejoiceth my intellect, true wit.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Offered by a child to an old man: which is wit-old.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: What is the figure? What is the figure?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Horns.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: Thou disputes like an Infant: go whip thy Jig.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p:
Lend me your Horn to make one, and I will whip
about your Infamy vnu cita a jig of a Cuckolds horn.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
If I had but one penny in the world thou shouldst
have it to buy Ginger bread: Hold, there is the very
Remuneration I had of thy Master, thou halfpenny
purse of wit, thou Pidgin-egg of discretion. O and the
heavens were so pleased, that thou wart but my Bastard;
What a joyful father wouldest thou make me?
Go to, thou hast it ad dungil at the fingers ends, as they say.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: O I smell false Latin, dunghel for vnguem.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p:
Arts-man perambulate, we will be singled from the
barbarous. Do you not educate youth at the Charge-House
on the top of the Mountain?

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: Or Mons the hill.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: At your sweet pleasure, for the Mountain.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: I do sans question.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
Sir, it is the Kings most sweet pleasure and affection,
to congratulate the Princess at her Pavilion, in the posteriors
of this day, which the rude multitude call the afternoon.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p:
The posterior of the day, most generous sir, is liable,
congruent, and measurable for the after noon: the word is
well culled, chose, sweet, and apt I do assure you sir, I do assure.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p:
Sir, the King is a noble Gentleman, and my familiar,
I do assure ye very good friend: for what is inward
between us, let it pass. I do beseech thee remember thy
courtesy. I beseech thee apparel thy head: and among other
important and most serious designs, and of great import indeed
too: but let that pass for I must tell thee it will
please his Grace (by the world) sometime to lean upon
my poor shoulder, and with his royal finger thus dally
with my excrement, with my moustache: but sweet heart
let that pass. By the world I recount no fable, some certain
special honours it pleaseth his greatness to impart to Armado
a Soldier, a man of travel, that hath seen the world: but
let that pass; the very all of all is: but sweet heart, I do implore
secrecy, that the King would have me present the Princess
(sweet chuck) with some delightful ostentation, or show,
or pageant, or antique, or firework: Now understanding
that the Curate and your sweet self, are good at such eruptions,
and sudden breaking out of mirth (as it were) I have
acquainted you withal, to the end to crave your assistance.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p:
Sir, you shall present before her the Nine Worthies,
Sir Holofernes, as concerning some entertainment of time,
some show in the posterior of this day, to be rendered by our
assistants the Kings command, and this most gallant illustrate
and learned Gentleman, before the Princess: I say
none so fit as to present the nine Worthies.

sp.speaker: Curat.
sp.p:
Where will you find men worthy enough to present
them?

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p:
Iosua, yourself, myself, and this gallant Gentleman
Iudas Machabeus; this Swain (because of his great limb
or joint) shall pass Pompey the great, the Page Hercules.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p:
Pardon sir, error: He is not quantity enough for
that worthies thumb, he is not so big as the end of his Club.

sp.speaker: Peda.
Page.
sp.p:
An excellent device: so if any of the audience hiss,
you may cry, Well done Hercules, now thou crushest the
Snake; that is the way to make an offence gracious, though
few have the grace to do it.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: For the rest of the Worthies?

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: I will play three myself.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Thrice worthy Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Shall I tell you a thing?

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: We attend.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p:
We will have, if this fadge not, an Antique. I beseech
you follow.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p:
Via good-man Dull, thou hast spoken no word all
this while.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Nor understood none neither sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Alone, we will employ thee.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p:
I will make one in a dance, or so: or I will play on
the Tabor to the worthies, and let them dance the hey.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: Most Dull, honest Dull, to our sport: away.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Sweet hearts we shall be rich ere we depart,
If Fairings come thus plentifully in.
A Lady walled about with Diamonds: Look you, what I
have from the loving King.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Madam, came nothing else along with that?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Nothing but this: yes as much love in Rime,
As would be crammed up in a sheet of paper
Writ on both sides the leaf, margent and all,
That he was fain to seal on Cupids name.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: That was the way to make his god-head Wax:
For he hath been five thousand year a Boy.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Aye and a shroud unhappy gallows too.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: You will never be friends with him, he killed your sister.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: He made her melancholy, sad, and heavy,
And so she died: had she been Light like you, of such a merry
nimble stirring spirit, she might have been Grandam ere she died.
And so may you: For a light heart lives long.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Whats your dark meaning mouse, of this light word?

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: A light condition in a beauty dark.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: We need more light to find your meaning out.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: You will mar the light by taking it in snuff:
Therefore I will darkly end the argument.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Look what you do, you do it still in the dark.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: So do not you, for you are a light Wench.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Indeed I weigh not you, and therefore light.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: You weigh me not, O that is you care not for me.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Great reason: for past care, is still past cure.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Well bandied both, a set of Wit well played.
But Rasaline, you have a Favour too?
Who sent it? and what is it?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I would you knew.
And if my face were but as fair as yours,
My Favour were as great, be witness this.
Nay I have Verses too, I thank Berowne,
The numbers true, and were the numbering too,
I were the fairest Goddess on the ground.
I am compared to twenty thousand fairs.
O he hath drawn my picture in his letter.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Anything like?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Much in the letters, nothing in the praise.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Beauteous as Ink: a good conclusion.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Fair as a text B in a Copy book.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Ware pencils, How? Let me not die your debtor,
My red Dominical, my golden letter,
O that your face were not so full of Oes.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: A Pox of that jest, and I beshrew all Shrews.
But Katherine what was sent to you
From fair Dumaine?

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Madam, this Glove.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Did he not send you twain?

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Yes Madam: and moreover,
Some thousand Verses of a faithful Lover.
A huge translation of hypocrisy,
Vildly compiled, profound simplicity.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: This, and these Pearl, to me sent Longauile.
The Letter is too long by half a mile.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I think no less: Dost thou not wish in heart
The Chain were longer, and the Letter short.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Aye, or I would these hands might never part.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: We are wise girls to mock our Lovers so.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: They are worse fools to purchase mocking so.
That same Berowne I will torture ere I go.
O that I knew he were but in by the week,
How I would make him fawn, and beg, and seek,
And wait the season, and observe the times,
And spend his prodigal wits in bootless rimes.
And shape his service wholly to my device,
And make him proud to make me proud that jests,
So perttaunt like would I archway his state,
That he should be my fool, and I his fate.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: None are so surely caught, when they are catched,
As Wit turned Fool, folly in Wisdom hatched:
Hath Wisdom's warrant, and the help of School,
And Wits own grace to grace a learned Fool.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: The blood of youth burns not with such excess,
As gravities revolt to wantons be.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Folly in Fools bears not so strong a note,
As foolery in the Wise, when Wit doth dote:
Since all the power thereof it doth apply,
To prove by Wit, worth in simplicity.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Here comes Boyet, and mirth is in his face.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: O I am stable with laughter, Where is her Grace?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Thy news Boyet?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Prepare Madam, prepare.
Arm Wenches arm, encounters mounted are,
Against your Peace Love doth approach, disguised:
Armed in arguments, You will be surprised.
Muster your Wits, stand in your own defence,
Or hide your heads like Cowards, and fly hence.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Saint Dennis to Saint Cupid: What are they,
That charge their breath against us? Say scout say.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Under the cool shade of a Sycamore,
I thought to close mine eyes some half an hour:
When lo to interrupt my purposed rest,
Toward that shade I might behold addressed,
The King and his companions warily,
I stole into a neighbour thicket by,
And overheard, what you shall over hear:
That by and by disguised they will be here.
Their Herald is a pretty knavish Page:
That well by heart hath conned his embassage
Action and accent did they teach him there.
Thus must thou speak, and thus thy body bear.
And ever and anon they made a doubt,
Presence majestical would put him out:
For quoth the King, an Angel shalt thou see:
Yet fear not thou but speak audaciously.
The Boy replied, An Angel is not evil:
I should have feared her had she been a devil.
With that all laughed, and clapped him on the shoulder,
Making the bold wag by their praises bolder.
One rubbed his elbow thus, and fleered, and swore,
A better speech was never spoke before.
Another with his finger and his thumb,
Cried via we will do it come what will come.
The third he capered and cried, All goes well.
The fourth turned on the toe, and down he fell:
With that they all did tumble on the ground,
With such a zealous laughter so profound,
That in this spleen ridiculous appears,
To check their folly passion's solemn tears.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: But what, but what, come they to visit us?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: They do, they do; and are apparelled thus,
Like Muscouites, or Russians, as I guess.
Their purpose is to parley, to court, and dance,
And every one his Love-feat will advance,
Unto his several Mistress: which they will know
By Favours several, which they did bestow.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: And will they so? the Gallants shall be tasked:
For Ladies; we will every one be masked,
And not a man of them shall have the grace
Despite of suit, to see a Ladies face.
Hold Rosaline, this Favour thou shalt wear,
And then the King will court thee for his Dear:
Hold take thou this my sweet, and give me thine,
So shall Berowne take me for Rosaline.
And change you Favours two, so shall your Loves
Woo contrary, deceived by these removes.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Come on then, wear the Favours most in sight.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: But in this changing, What is your intent?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: The effect of my intent is to cross theirs:
They do it but in mockery merriment,
And mock for mock is only my intent,
Their several counsels they unbosom shall,
To Loves mistook, and so be mocked withal.
Upon the next occasion that we meet,
With Visages displayed to talk and greet.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: But shall we dance, if they desire us toot?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: No, to the death we will not move a foot,
Nor to their penned speech render we no grace:
But while it is spoke each turn away his face.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Why that contempt will kill the speakers heart,
And quite divorce his memory from his part.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Therefore I do it, and I make no doubt,
The rest will ere come in, if he be out.
There is no such sport, as sport by sport overthrown:
To make theirs ours, and ours none but our own.
So shall we stay mocking intended game,
And they well mocked depart away with shame.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: The Trumpet sounds, be masked, the maskers come.

div2.stage: Enter Black-moores with musicke, the Boy with a speach, and the rest of the Lordes disguysed.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: All hail, the richest Beauties on the earth.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: Beauties no richer than rich Taffeta.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: A holy parcel of the fairest dames that ever turned their
sp.p: backs to mortal views.

div2.stage: The Ladyes turne their backes to him.

sp.speaker: Berow,
sp.l: Their eyes villain, their eyes.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: That even turned their eyes to mortal views.
Out

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: True, out indeed.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: Out of your favours heavenly spirits vouchsafe
Not to behold.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: Once to behold, rogue.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Once to behold with your Sun beamed eyes,
With your Sun beamed eyes.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: They will not answer to that Epithet.
You were best call it Daughter beamed eyes.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: They do not mark me, and that brings me out.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Is this your perfectness? begone you rogue.

sp.speaker: Rosal.
sp.l: What would these strangers?
Know their minds Boyet.
If they do speak our language, it is our will
That some plain man recount their purposes.
Know what they would?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: What would you with the Princes?

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: Nothing but peace, and gentle visitation.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: What would they, say they?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Nothing but peace, and gentle visitation.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Why that they have, and bid them so be gon.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: She says you have it, and you may be gon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Say to her we have measured many miles,
To tread a Measure with her on this grass.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: They say that they have measured many a mile,
To tread a Measure with you on this grass.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: It is not so. Ask them how many inches
Is in one mile? If they have measured many,
The measure then of one is easily told.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: If to come hither, you have measured miles,
And many miles: the Princess bids you tell,
How many inches doth fill up one mile?

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: Tell her we measure them by weary steps.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: She hears herself.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: How many weary steps,
Of many weary miles you have over gone,
Are numbered in the travail of one Mile?

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: We number nothing that we spend for you,
Our duty is so rich, so infinite,
That we may do it still without accompt.
Vouchsafe to show the sunshine of your face,
That we (like savages) may worship it.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: My face is but a Moon, and clouded too.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Blessed are clouds, to do as such clouds do.
Vouchsafe bright Moon, and these thy Stars to shine,
(Those clouds removed) upon our watery eyen.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: O vain petitioner, beg a greater matter,
Thou now requests but Moonshine in the water.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then in our measure, do but vouchsafe one change,
Thou biddest me beg, this begging is not strange.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Play Music then: nay you must do it soon.
Not yet no dance: thus change I like the Moon.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Will you not dance? How come you thus estranged?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: You took the moon at full, but now she is changed?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet still she is the Moon, and I the Man.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: The music plays, vouchsafe some motion to it,
Our ears vouchsafe it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But your legs should do it.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Since you are strangers, and come here by chance,
We will not be nice, take hands, we will not dance.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why take we hands then?

sp.speaker: Rosa,
sp.l: Only to part friends.
Curtsy sweet hearts, and so the Measure ends.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: More measure of this measure be not nice.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: We can afford no more at such a price.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Prise you yourselves: What buys your company?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Your absence only.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: That can never be.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Then cannot we be bought: and so adieu,
Twice to your Visor, and half once to you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: If you deny to dance, let us hold more chat.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: In private then.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I am best pleased with that.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: White handed Mistress, one sweet word with thee.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Honey, and Milk, and Sugar: there is three.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Nay then two trays, an if you grow so nice,
Metheglin, Wort, and Malmsey; well run dice:
There is half a dozen sweets.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Seventh sweet adieu, since you can cog,
I will play no more with you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: One word in secret.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Let it not be sweet.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Thou grievest my gall.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Gall, bitter,

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Therefore meet.

sp.speaker: Duman.
sp.l: Will you vouchsafe with me to change a word?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Name it.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: Fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Say you so? Fair Lord, take that for your fair Lady

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: Please it you, as much in private, and I will bid adieu.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: What, was your vizard made without a tongue?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I know the reason (Lady) why you ask.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: O for your reason, quickly sir, I long?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You have a double tongue within your Mask,
And would afford my speechless vizard half.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Veal quoth the Dutch-man: is not veal a Calf?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: A Calf fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, a fair Lord Calf.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Let us part the word?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, I will not be your half:
Take all and wean it, it may prove an Ox.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Look how you butt yourself in these sharpe mocks,
Will you give horns chaste Lady? do not so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then die a Calf, before your horns do grow.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: One word in private with you ere I die.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Bleat softly then, the Butcher hears you cry.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: The tongues of mocking Wenches are as keen
As is the Razors edge invisible:
Cutting a smaller hair than may be seen,
Above the sense of sense so sensible,
Seemeth their conference, their conceits have wings,
Fleeter than Arrows, bullets wind thought swifter things.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Not one word more my Maids, break off, break off.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: By heaven, all dry beaten with pure scoff.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Farewell mad Wenches, you have simple wits.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Twenty adieus my frozen Muskouits.
Are these the breed of Wits so wondered at?

sp.speaker: Boye.
sp.l: Tapers they are with your sweet breaths puffed out.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Well-liking Wits they have gross gross, fat fat.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: O poverty in wit, Kingly poor flout.
Will they not (think you) hang themselves tonight?
Or ever but in vizards show their faces.
This pert Berowne was out of countenance quite.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: They were all in lamentable cases,
The King was weeping ripe for a good word.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Berowne did swear himself out of all suite.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Dumaine was at my service, and his sword,
No point (quoth I) my servant, straight was mute.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Lord Longauill said I came over his heart:
And trow you what he called me?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Qualm perhaps.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Yes in good faith.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Go sickness as thou art.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Well, better wits have worn plain statute Caps.
But will you hear; the King is my Love sworn.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: And quick Berowne hath plighted Faith to me.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: And Longauill was for my service born.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Dumaine is mine as sure as bark on tree.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Madam, and pretty mistresses give ear.
Immediately they will again be here,
In their own shapes: for it can never be,
They will digest this harsh indignity.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Will they return?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: They will they will, God knows,
And leap for joy, though they are lame with blows:
Therefore change Favours, and when they repair,
Blow like sweet Roses, in this summer air.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: How blow? how blow? Speak to be understood.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Fair Ladies masked, are Roses in their bud:
Dismasked, their damask sweet commixture shown,
Are Angels veiling clouds, or Roses blown.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Avaunt perplexity, What shall we do,
If they return in their own shapes to woe?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Good Madam, if by me you will be advised,
Let us mock them still as well known as disguised:
Let us complain to them what fools were hear,
Disguised like Muscouities in shapeless gear:
And wonder what they were, and to what end
Their shallow shows, and Prologue vildly penned.
And their rough carriage so ridiculous,
Should be presented at our Tent to us.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Ladies, withdraw: the gallants are at hand,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Whip to our Tents as Roes runs over land.

div2.stage: Enter the King and the rest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fair sir, God save you: Where is the Princess?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Gone to her Tent. Please it your Majesty command
me any service to her thither,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: That she vouchsafe me audience for one word.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I will, and so will she, I know my Lord.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: This fellow pecks up Wit as Pigeons Peas,
And utters it again when God doth please.
He is Wits Peddler, and retails his wares:
At Wakes and Wassels, meetings, markets, Fairs.
And we that sell by gross, the Lord doth know,
Have not the grace to grace it with such show.
This Gallant pins the Wenches on his sleeve.
Had he been Adam he had tempted Eve.
He can carve too, and lisp: Why this is he
That kissed his hand, a way in courtesy.
This is the Ape of Form, Monsieur the nice,
That when he plays at Tables chides the Dice
In honourable terms; nay he can sing
A mean most meanly, and in ushering.
Mend him who can, the Ladies call him sweet.
The stairs as he treads on them kiss his feet.
This is the flower that smiles on everyone.
To show his teeth as white as Whales bone.
And consciences that will not die in debt,
Pay him the due of honey-tongued Boyet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A blister on his sweet tongue with my heart,
That put Armathoes Page out of his part.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: See where it comes. Behaviour what wert thou?
Till this mad man showed thee, and what art thou now?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: All hail sweet Madam, and fair time of day.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Fair in all Hail is foul, as I conceive.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Construe my speeches better, if you may.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Then wish me better, I will give you leave.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We came to visit you, and purpose now,
To lead you to our Court, vouchsafe it then.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: This Field shall hold me, and so hold your vow:
Nor God nor I delights in perjured men.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Rebuke me not for that which you provoke:
The virtue of your eye must break my oath.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: You nickname virtue, vice you should have spoke:
For vertues office never breaks men's troth.
Now by my maiden honour yet as pure,
As the unsullied Lily I protest,
A world of torments though I should endure,
I would not yield to be your houses guest:
So much I hate a breaking cause to be
Of heavenly Oaths vowed with integrity.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O you have lived in desolation here,
Unseen, unvisited, much to our shame.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Not so my Lord, it is not so I swear,
We have had pastimes here and pleasant game,
A mess of Russians left us but of late.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How Madam? Russians?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Aye in truth My Lord.
Trim gallants, full of Courtship and of state.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Madam speak true: It is not so my Lord:
My Lady (to the manner of the days)
In courtesy gives undeserving praise.
We four indeed confronted were with four,
In Russian habit: here they stayed an hour,
And talked apace: and in that hour (my Lord)
They did not bless us with one happy word.
I dare not call them fools; but this I think,
When they are thirsty, fools would fain have drink.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: This jest is dry to me, gentle sweet,
Your wits makes wise things foolish when we greet
With eyes best seeing, heavens fiery eye:
By light we lose light, your capacity
Is of that nature, that to your huge store,
Wise things seem foolish, and rich things but poor.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: This proves you wise and rich: for in my eye.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: I am a fool, and full of poverty.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: But that you take what doth to you belong,
It were a fault to snatch words from my tongue.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O, I am yours and all that I possess.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: All the fool mine.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I cannot give you less.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Which of the Vizards was it that you wore?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Where, when, what Vizard? why demand you this?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: There, then, that Vizard, that superfluous case,
That hid the worse, and showed the better face.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We were descried, they will mock us now downright.

sp.speaker: Duman.
sp.l: Let us confess and turn it to a jest.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Amazed my Lord? Why looks your highness sad?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Help hold his brows, he will sound: why look
you pale?
Sea sick I think coming from Muscouie.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Thus pour the Stars down plagues for perjury.
Can any face of brass hold longer out?
Here stand I, Lady dart thy skill at me,
Bruise me with scorn, confound me with a flout.
Thrust thy sharpe wit quite through my ignorance,
Cut me to pieces with thy keen conceit.
And I will wish thee never more to dance,
Nor never more in Russian habit wait.
O never will I trust to speeches penned,
Nor to the motion of a Schoolboy's tongue:
Nor never come in vizard to my friend,
Nor woo in rime like a blind harpers song.
Taffeta phrases, silken terms precise,
Three piled Hyperboles, spruce affection:
Figures pedantical, these summer flies,
Have blown me full of maggot ostentation.
I do forswear them, and I here protest,
By this white Glove (how white the hand God knows)
Henceforth my wooing mind shall be expressed
In russet yeas, and honest kersey noes.
And to begin Wench, so God help me law,
My love to thee is sound, sance crack or flaw.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Sans, sans, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Yet I have a trick,
Of the old rage: bear with me, I am sick.
I will leave it by degrees; soft, let us see,
Write
Lord have mercy on us,
on those three,
They are infected, in their hearts it lies:
They have the Plague, and caught it of your eyes,
These Lords are visited, you are not free,
For the Lords tokens on you do I see.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: No, they are free that gave these tokens to us.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: Our states are forfeit, seek not to undo us.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: It is not so, for how can this be true,
That you stand forfeit, being those that sue.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Peace, for I will not have to do with you.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Nor shall not, if I do as I intend.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Speak for yourselves, my wit is at an end.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Teach us sweet Madam, for our rude transgression
Some fair excuse.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: The fairest is confession.
Were not you here but even now, disguised?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Madam, I was.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: And were you well advised?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I was fair Madam.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: When you then were here,
What did you whisper in your Ladies ear?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: That more than all the world, I did respect her.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: When she shall challenge this, you will reject her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Upon mine honour no.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Peace peace, forbear: your Oath once broke, you
force not to forswear.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Despise me when I break this oath of mine.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I will, and therefore keep it. Rosaline,
What did the Russian whisper in your ear?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Madam, he swore that he did hold me dear,
As precious eyesight, and did value me
Above this World: adding thereto more over,
That he would wed me, or else die my Lover.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: God give thee joy of him: the Noble Lord
Most honourably doth uphold his word,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What mean you Madam: by my life my troth,
I never swore this Lady such an oath.

sp.speaker: Rosal.
sp.l: By heaven you did; and to confirm it plain,
You gave me this: but take it sir again.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My faith and this, the Princess I did give,
I knew her by this Jewel on her sleeve.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Pardon me sir, this Jewel did she wear,
And Lord Berowne (I thank him) is my dear.
What? will you have me, or your Pearl again?

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: Neither of either: I remit both twain.
I see the trick of it: here was a consent,
Knowing aforehand of our merriment,
To dash it like a Christmas Comedy:
Some carry tale, some please-man, some sleight said:
Some mumble news, some trencher Knight, some Dick
That smiles, his cheek in years, and knows the trick
To make my Lady laugh, when she is disposed:
Told our intents before: which once disclosed,
The Ladies did change Favours; and then we
Following the signs, wood but the sign of she,
Now to our perjury, to add more terror,
We are again forsworn in will and error.
Much upon this it is: and might not you
Forestall our sport, to make us thus untrue?
Do not you know my Ladies foot by the squire?
And laugh upon the apple of her eye?
And stand between her back sir and the fire,
Holding a trencher, jesting merrily?
You put our Page out: go, you are allowed.
Die when you will, a Smock shall be your shroud.
You leer upon me, do you: there is an eye
Wounds like a leaden sword.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: Full merely hath this brave nuage, this career
been run.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Lo, he is tilting straight. Peace, I have don.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Welcome pure wit, thou partest a fair fray.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: O Lord sir, they would know,
Whether the three Worthies shall come in or no?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What, are there but three?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: No sir, but it is very fine,
For every one presents three.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: And three times thrice is nine.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Not so sir, under correction sir, I hope it is not so.
You cannot beg us sir, I can assure you sir, we know what
we know: I hope sir three times thrice sir.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Is not nine.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Under correction sir we know where-until it doth
amount.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: By Ioue, I always took three threes for nine.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
O Lord sir, it were pity you should get your living
by reckoning sir.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: How much is it?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
O Lord sir, the parties themselves, the actors sir
will show where-until it doth amount: for mine own part, I
am (as thy say, but to perfect one man in one poor man)
Pompion the great sir.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Art thou one of the Worthies?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
It pleased them to think me worthy of Pompey
the great: for mine own part I know not the degree of the
Worthy, but I am to stand for him.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Go bid them prepare.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: We will turn it finely off sir, we will take some care.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Berowne, they will shame us: let them not approach.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: We are shame proof my Lord: and it is some policy
To have one show worse than the Kings and his company.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I say they shall not come.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Nay my good Lord let me over-rule you now.
That sport best pleases, that doth best know how:
Where zeal strives to content, and the contents
Dies in the zeal of that which it presents:
Their form confounded, makes most form in mirth,
When great things labouring perish in their birth.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: A right description of our sport my Lord.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p:
Anointed, I implore so much expense of thy royal
sweet breath, as will utter a brace of words.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Doth this man serve God?

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Why ask you?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: He speaks not like a man of God his making.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p:
That is all one my fair sweet honey monarch,
For I protest, the Schoolmaster is exceeding fantastical,
Too too vain, too too vain: but we will put it (as they say)
to Fortuna delaguar, I wish you the peace of mind most royal
couplement.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Here is like to be a good presence of Worthies:
He presents Hector of Troy, the Swain Pompey the great, the
parish Curate Alexander, Armadoes Page Hercules, the Pedant
Iudas Machabeus: And if these four Worthies in their
first show thrive, these four will change habits, and present
the other five.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: There is five in the first show.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You are deceived, it is not so.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: The Pedant, the Bragart, the Hedge-Priest, the
Fool, and the Boy,
Abate throw at Novum, and the whole world again,
Cannot pick out five such, take each one in his vain.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: The Ship is under sail, and here she comes amain.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: I Pompey am.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: You lie, you are not he.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I Pompey am,

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p: With Libbards head on knee.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Well said old mocker, I must needs be friends with thee.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I Pompey am, Pompey surnamed the big.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.p: The great.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
It is great sir,
Pompey surnamed the great.
That oft in field with Targe and Shield did make my foe to sweat,
And travelling along this coast I here am come by chance,
And lay my Arms before the Legs of this sweet Lass of France.
If your Ladyship would say thanks Pompey, I had done.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Great thanks great Pompey.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
It is not so much worth: but I hope I was perfect. I
made a little fault in great.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p:
My hat to a halfpenny, Pompey proves the best
Worthy.

sp.speaker: Curat.
sp.l: When in the world I lived, I was the worlds commander:
By East, West, North, and South, I spread my conquering might:
My Scutcheon plain declares that I am Alisander.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p: Your Nose says no, you are not: for it stands too right.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: Your nose smells no in his most tender smelling knight.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: The conqueror is dismayed: proceed good Alexander.

sp.speaker: Cura.
sp.l: When in the world I lived, I was the worlds commander.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Most true, it is right: you were so Alisander.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: Pompey the great.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Your servant and Costard.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: Take away the Conqueror, take away Alisander.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
O sir, you have overthrown Alisander the Conqueror:
you will be scrapped out of the painted cloth for this.
Your Lion that holds his Polax sitting on a close stool,
will be given to Aiax. He will be the ninth Worthy: a Conqueror, and afeared to speak? Run away for shame Alisander.
There if it shall please you a foolish mild man, an
honest man; look you, and soon dashed. He is a marvelous
good neighbour faith, and a very good Bowler: but for
Alisander, alas you see how it is a little overparted, but there
are Worthies acoming will speak their mind in some
other sort.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Stand aside good Pompey.

div2.stage: Enter Pedant for Iudas, and the Boy for Hercules.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.l: Great Hercules is presented by this Imp,
Whose Club killed Cerberus that three headed Canus,
And when he was a babe, a child, a shrimp,
Thus did he strangle Serpents in his Manus,
Quoniam, he seemeth in minority,
Ergo, I come with this Apology.
Keep some state in thy exit, and vanish.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.l: Iudas I am.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.p: A Iudas.

sp.speaker: Pedan.
sp.l: Not Iscariot sir.
Iudas I am, yclept Machabeus.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.p: Iudas Machabeus clipped, is plain Iudas.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: A kissing traitor, How art thou proud Iudas?

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.l: Iudas I am.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.p: The more shame for you Iudas.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.l: What mean you sir?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p: To make Iudas hang himself.

sp.speaker: Pedan.
sp.l: Begin sir, you are my elder.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: Well followed, Iudas was hanged on an Elder.

sp.speaker: Pedan.
sp.l: I will not be put out of countenance.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: Because thou hast no face.

sp.speaker: Pedan.
sp.l: What is this?

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p: A Cittern head.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.p: The head of a Bodkin.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: A deaths face in a Ring.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: The face of an old Roman coin, scarce seen.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p: The pummel of Caesars Fauchion.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.p: The carved bone face on a Flask.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: Saint Georges half cheek in a Brooch.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.p: Aye and in a Brooch of Lead.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p:
Aye and worn in the cap of a Tooth-drawer:
And now forward, for we have put thee in countenance.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: You have put me out of countenance.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: False, we have given thee faces.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: But you have out-faced them all.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: If thou wert a Lion, we would do so.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p:
Therefore as he is, an Ass, let him go:
And so adieu sweet Iude. Nay, Why dost thou stay?

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.p: For the latter end of his name.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: For the Ass to the Iude: give it him. Judas away.

sp.speaker: Peden.
sp.l: This is not generous, not gentle, not humble.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.l: A light for Monsieur Judas, it grows dark, he
may stumble.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Alas poor Machabeus, how hath he been baited.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Hide thy head Achilles, here comes Hector in Arms.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.p:
Though my mocks come home by me, I will
now be merry.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Hector was but a Troyan in respect of this.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p: But is this Hector?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I think Hector was not so clean timbered.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: His Leg is too big for Hectors.

sp.speaker: Duman.
sp.p: More Calf certain.

sp.speaker: Boye.
sp.p: No, he is best endued in the small.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: This cannot be Hector.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.p: He is a God or a Painter: for he makes faces.

sp.speaker: Braggart.
sp.l: The Omnipotent Mars, of Lances the almighty,
gave Hector a gift.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.p: A gift Nutmeg.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: A Lemon.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Stuck with Cloves.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.p: No cloven.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.l: Peace. The Omnipotent Mars, of Lances the almighty,
Gave Hector a gift, the heir of Illion,
A man so breathed, that certain he would fight; yea,
From morn till night out of his Pavilion.
I am that Flower.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.p: That Mint.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: That Cullambine.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.l: Sweet Lord Longauill rain thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
I must rather give it the rain: for it runs against
Hector.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.p: Aye and Hector is a Greyhound.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.l: The sweet War-man is dead and rotten,
Sweet chucks beat not the bones of the buried:
When he breathed he was a man:
But I will forward with my device; sweet royalty bestow
on me the sense of hearing.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Speak brave Hector, we are much delighted.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.l: I do adore thy sweet Graces Slipper.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p: Loves her by the foot.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.p: He may not by the yard.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.l: This Hector far surmounted Hanniball.
The party is gone.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Fellow Hector, she is gone; she is two months on
her way.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: What meanest thou?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Faith unless you play the honest Troyan, the poor
wench is cast away: she is quick, the child brags in her
belly already: it is yours.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p:
Dost thou infamonize me among potentates:
Thou shalt die.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Then shall Hector be whipped for Iaquenetta that is
quick by him, and hanged for Pompey that is dead by him.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.p: Most rare Pompey.

sp.speaker: Boyet.
sp.p: Renowned Pompey.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p:
Greater than great, great, great, great Pompey: Pompey
the huge.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.p: Hector trembles.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p:
Pompey is moved more Ates more Ates stir them
or stir them on.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.p: Hector will challenge him.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p:
Aye, if he have no more man's blood in his belly than will
sup a Flea.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: By the North Pole I do challenge thee.

sp.speaker: Clow.
Duma.
sp.p: Room for the incensed Worthies.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I will do it in my shirt.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.p: Most resolute Pompey.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Master, let me take you a button hole lower. Do
you not see, Pompey is uncasing for the Combat: What
mean you? you will lose your reputation.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p:
Gentlemen and Soldiers, pardon me, I will not
combat in my shirt.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.p: You may not deny it, Pompey hath made the challenge.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Sweet bloods, I both may and will.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: What reason have you for it.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p:
The naked truth of it is, I have no Shirt.
I go Woolward for penance.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
True, and it was enjoined him in Rome for want of
Linen: since when, I will be sworn he wore none, but a dishcloth
of Jaquenettaes, and that he wears next his heart for a
Favour.

sp.speaker: Marcad.
sp.p: God save you Madam.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p:
Welcome Marcade, but that thou interruptest our
merriment.

sp.speaker: Marcad.
sp.p:
I am sorry Madam for the news I bring
is heavy in my tongue. The King your father

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Dead for my life.

sp.speaker: Marcad.
sp.p: Even so: my tale is told.

sp.speaker: B er.
sp.l: Worthies away, the Scene begins to cloud.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p:
For mine own part I breath free breath: I have
seen the day of wrong through the little hole of discretion,
and I will right myself like a Soldier.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How fares your Majesty?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Boyet prepare, I will away tonight.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Madam Not so, I do beseech you stay.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Prepare I say: I thank you gracious Lords
For all your fair endeavours and entreat:
Out of a new sad-soul, that you vouchsafe,
In your rich wisdom to excuse, or hide,
The liberal opposition of our spirits,
If overboldly we have borne ourselves,
In the converse of breath (your gentleness
Was guilty of it.) Farewell worthy Lord:
A heavy heart bears not a humble tongue.
Excuse me so coming too short of thanks,
For my great suit, so easily obtained.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The extreme parts of time extremely forms,
All causes to the purpose of his speed:
And often at his very loss decides
That, which long process could not arbitrate.
And though the mourning brow of progeny
Forbid the smiling courtesy of Love,
The holy suite which fain it would convince,
Yet since Loves argument was first on foot,
Let not the cloud of Sorrow jostle it
From what it purposed, since to wail friends lost,
Is not by much so wholesome profitable,
As to rejoice at friends but newly found.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I understand you not, my griefs are double.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.l: Honest plain words, best pearce the ear of grief,
And by these badges understand the King,
For your fair sakes, have we neglected time.
Played foul-play with our oaths: your beauty Ladies
Hath much deformed us, fashioning our humours
Even to the opposed end of our ententes.
And what in us hath seemed ridiculous:
As Love is full of unbefitting strains,
All wanton as a child, skipping and vain.
Formed by the eye, and therefore like the eye.
Full of straying shapes, of habits and of forms:
Varying in subjects as the eye doth roll,
To every varied object in his glance:
Which party coated presence of loose love
Put on by us, if in your heavenly eyes,
Have misbecome our oaths and gravities.
Those heavenly eyes that look into these faults,
Suggested us to make, therefore Ladies
Our love being yours, the error that Love makes
Is likewise yours: we to ourselves prove false,
By being once false, for ever to be true
To those that make us both fair Ladies you.
And even that falsehood in itself a sin,
Thus purifies itself and turns to grace.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: We have received your Letters, full of Love:
Your Favours, ambassadors of Love.
And in our maiden counsel rated them,
At courtship pleasant jest and courtesy,
As bombast and as lining to the time:
But more devout than this our respects,
Have we not been, and therefore met your Loves,
In their own fashion like a merriment.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Our letters madam, showed much more than jest.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: So did our looks.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: We did not cote them so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now at the latest minute of the hour,
Grant us your loves.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: A time methinks too short,
To make a world-without-end bargain in:
No no my Lord, your Grace is perjured much,
Full of dear guiltiness, and therefore this,
If for my Love (as there is no such cause)
You will do aught, this shall you do for me:
Your oath I will not trust, but go with speed
To some forlorn and naked Hermitage,
Remote from all the pleasures of the world:
There stay until the twelve Celestial Signs
Have brought about the annual reckoning.
If this Austere unsociable life,
Change not your offer made in heat of blood.
If frosts and fasts, hard lodging, and thin weeds,
Nip not the gaudy blossoms of your Love:
But that it bear this trial, and last Love,
Then at the expiration of the year,
Come challenge me, challenge me by these deserts:
And by this Virgin palm now kissing thine,
I will be thine: and till that instance shut
My woeful self up in a mourning house,
Raining the tears of lamentation,
For the remembrance of my Fathers death.
If this thou do deny, let our hands part,
Neither intitled in the others heart.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: If this, or more than this, I would deny,
To flatter up these powers of mine with rest,
The sudden hand of death close up mine eye.
Hence hermit then my heart, is in thy breast.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: And what to me my Love? and what to me?

sp.speaker: Rosal.
sp.l: You must be purged too, your sins are racked.
You are attaint with faults and perjury:
Therefore if you my favour mean to get,
A twelve-month shall you spend and never rest,
But seek the weary beds of people sick.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: But what to me my Love? but what to me?

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: A wife?
a beard, fair health, and honesty,
With three fold love I wish you all these three.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: O shall I say, I thank you gentle Wife?

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Not so my Lord, a twelve-month and a day,
I will mark no words that smooth-faced wooers say,
Come when the King doth to my Lady come:
Then if I have much love, I will give you some.

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.l: I will serve thee true and faithfully till then.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Yet swear not, lest ye be forsworn again.

sp.speaker: Longauill.
sp.l: What says Maria?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: At the twelve-months end,
I will change my black Gown for a faithful friend.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I will stay with patience, but the time is long.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: The liker you, few taller are so young.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: Studies my Lady? Mistress look on me,
Behold the window of my heart, mine eye:
What humble suite attends thy answer there,
Impose some service on me for thy Love.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Oft have I heard of you my Lord Berowne,
Before I saw you: and the worlds large tongue
Proclaims you for a man replete with mocks,
Full of comparisons and wounding flouts:
Which you on all estates will execute,
That lie within the mercy of your wit
To weed this wormwood from your fruitful brain,
And therewithal to win me, if you please,
Without the which I am not to be won:
You shall this twelve-month term from day to day,
Visit the speechless sick, and still converse,
With groaning wretches: and your task shall be,
With all the fierce endeavour of your wit,
To enforce the pained impotent to smile.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: To move wild laughter in the throat of death?
It cannot be, it is impossible.
Mirth cannot move a soul in agony.

sp.speaker: Rosal.
sp.l: Why that is the way to choake a gibing spirit,
Whose influence is begot of that loose grace,
Which shallow laughing hearers give to fools,
A jests prosperity lies in the ear,
Of him that hears it, never in the tongue
Of him that makes it: then if sickly ears
Deafed with the clamours of their own dear groans,
Will hear your idle scorns; continue then,
And I will have you, and that fault withal.
But if they will not, throw away that spirit,
And I shall find you empty of that fault,
Right joyful of your reformation.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: A twelve-month? well; befall what will befall,
I will jest a twelve-month in an Hospital.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Aye sweet my Lord, and so I take my leave.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No Madam, we will bring you on your way.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: Our wooing doth not end like an old Play:
Iacke hath not Gill: these Ladies courtesy
Might well have made our sport a Comedy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come sir, it wants a twelve-month and a day,
And then it will end.

sp.speaker: Berow.
sp.l: That is too long for a Play.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Sweet Majesty vouchsafe me.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Was not that Hector?

sp.speaker: Duma.
sp.p: The worthy Knight of Troy.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p:
I will kiss thy royal finger, and take leave.
I am a Votary; I have vowed to Iaquenetta
To hold the Plough for her sweet love three year.
But most esteemed greatness, will you hear the Dialogue
that the two Learned men have compiled, in praise of the
Owl and the Cuckoo? it should have followed in the
end of our show.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Call them forth quickly, we will do so.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Holla. Approach.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p:
This side is Hiems, Winter.
This Ver, the Spring: The one maintained by the Owl,
the other by the Cuckoo.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Ver begin.

sp.l: When Daisies pied, and Violets blue,
And Cuckoo-buds of yellow hew:
And Lady-smocks all silver white,
Do paint the Meadows with delight:
The Cuckoo then on every tree,
Mocks married men; for thus singes he,
Cuckoo.
Cuckoo, Cuckoo: O word of fear,
Unpleasing to a married ear.
When Shepherds pipe on Oaten Straws,
And merry Larks are Ploughmen's Clocks:
When Turtles tread and Rooks and Daws,
And Maidens bleach their summer smocks:
The Cuckoo then on every tree,
Mocks married men, for thus singes he,
Cuckoo.
Cuckoo, cuckoo: O word of fear,
Unpleasing to a married ear.
When Icicles hang by the wall,
And Dicke the Shepherd blows his nail:
And Thom bears Logs into the hall,
And Milk comes frozen home in pail:
When Blood is nipped, and ways be full,
Then nightly singes the staring Owl
Tu-whit to-who.
A merry note,
While greasy Ione doth keel the pot.
When all aloud the wind doth blow,
And coughing drowns the Parsons saw;
And Birds sit brooding in the Snow,
And Marian's nose looks red and raw:
When roasted Crabs hiss in the bowl,
Then nightly singes the staring Owl,
Tu-whit to-who.
A merry note,
While greasy Ione doth keel the pot.

sp.p:
The words of Mercury, are harsh after the
songs of Apollo.
